Title: "Ananse Festival: Storytelling for Peace"
Quote:
The ANANSE Literary Festival promoted a narrative of peace through education and literature in
vulnerable communities of Luanda, Angola, by organizing a 3-day literature and culture festival. The Ananse project addressed critical issues such as the lack of education and basic literacy, the
decolonization of traditional Angolan and African knowledge transmission, and the failure to incorporate
creative and traditional methods into children's and youth education. The project empowered young
people from the provinces of Cunene, Benguela, Huila, and Huambo by providing them with intensive
training in oral storytelling, creative writing, cultural journalism, and audiovisual production. This initiative
culminated in a 3-day literature and culture festival. By doing so, it strengthened cultural preservation,
created new forms of educational inclusion, amplified marginalized discourse, expanded access to
knowledge, and improved dialogue between traditional Angolan communities.  The festival, which was freely accessible to young people and children, is part of the
second phase of this project, which took place over three days in 3 different spaces, among them: the
school complex on the outskirts of Luanda (Lar de Nazaré), a place with a high illiteracy rate, the BAI
Academy university and the peripheral arts center Horizonte Njinga Mbandi. The festival was attended by a total of 2000 people. In addition to the presentation of the projects of the young trainees, 12
discussion tables and 15 interactive cultural activities were held, always anchored in Angolan narratives
collected in trips and interviews with local communities.  "The ANANSE Festival taught me that storytelling is also building peace. I have found that Angolan oral
literature can be a powerful tool to unite generations, create empathy and inspire social change." The ANANSE Festival promoted an inclusive space that connected young people, educators and
communities around literature and storytelling. In the short term, it offered new tools to students and
cultural access to vulnerable communities. In the long run, it strengthens a network of educators and
young creators who can replicate the methodology.

Title: “Divine Footprints:” Using Musical Theatre to tell Sacred Stories
Quote:
This project leveraged theatre’s unique capacity as a peacebuilding tool by fusing the genre of
Broadway with folk and classical Indian performance traditions to tell the life story of Siddhartha Gautama,
the Buddha, in the form of an original musical. Convened through a series of workshops, artists and
scholars from across India collaborated to develop the piece while critically engaging questions of
religious violence and articulating possibilities for more harmonious coexistence in a South Asian context. Despite strong synergies between my skillset and the proposed project, bringing my vision to life
proved to be enormously challenging and rewarding. Early on, I encountered persistent obstacles in
building partnerships and managing logistics from the United States, even though I was collaborating
closely with a local partner. Given these difficulties, I chose to pivot from a single summer-long formal
workshop to multiple shorter, more flexible sessions that targeted specific elements of the theatrical
process. Narrowing the project’s thematic focus to Buddhism also proved beneficial, allowing me to better
align my existing knowledge with the content of the workshops while further deepening discussions on its
current social and political implications.  Just as the workshop model of theatre-making is shaped by conversations and
shared experiences of its participants, our understanding of peace emerges through ongoing reflection... peace is found in our willingness to
interrogate practices that sustain discrimination and oppression. Art, and particularly theatre, offers a
powerful vehicle through which to undertake this work and the story of the Buddha provides the perfect
backdrop.

Title: A Thousand Voices – Amplifying Afghan Youth Voices
A World of Possibilities: Enhancing Mental Health and Leadership Skills for Girls in Pakistan
Quote:
This project addressed the lack of mental health support and leadership opportunities for young women in Pakistan through the Stories of Strength initiative. Using reading circles, journaling workshops, and mentorship from mental health professionals in collaboration with Ascend Pakistan, the program
promoted resilience, self-expression, and leadership development among participants. The project’s approach centered on building a strong, culturally aware team and fostering community
participation to ensure relevance and impact. I worked with mental health professionals who understand
Pakistan’s societal barriers and engaged local leaders, parents, teachers, and the girls themselves in
shaping the program. Together, we designed interactive workshops that integrated mental health
education with practical coping tools within a supportive environment that reduced stigma and
encouraged peer connection.  For me, peace is not just the absence of conflict but the presence of fairness, equality, and dignity for all.
It means creating conditions where all people, especially girls and women, can live free of fear, express
themselves fully, and pursue their dreams without barriers imposed by society. My project contributes to
peace by addressing the silent struggles of young women in Pakistan, particularly the stigma around
mental health and the lack of leadership opportunities. In the short term, the project created safe spaces
where girls could openly share their experiences, gain coping strategies, and feel connected to a
supportive community. To ensure long-term sustainability, we trained peer leaders and equipped them
with resources. We provided them with toolkits that included workshop outlines, reading materials, and
guidance on leading discussions. By empowering girls within the community to become leaders, the
project reduces dependency on external facilitators and builds local ownership. This approach not only
sustains the program but also creates a ripple effect, as peer leaders mentor future participants, expand
outreach, and adapt activities to evolving needs within their communities.

Title: Ability in Education
Quote:
Our project addressed the lack of educational and career opportunities for students with physical
disabilities in rural Turkmenistan by equipping them with digital design and 3D modeling skills. Working in
partnership with American Space Mary, we provided hands-on training, tablets, and access to 3D printing
technology for 27 participants, fostering both technical knowledge and a supportive community. I initially set out to provide information and guidance on higher education pathways for youth with physical
disabilities in Turkmenistan. Our original plan focused on college preparation and scholarship guidance. However, systemic barriers
made this unrealistic and potentially discouraging for participants. In response, we shifted to teaching 3D
modeling and printing—an area that gave participants tangible skills, confidence, and career possibilities.
This adjustment kept us aligned with the project’s core goal of empowerment while respecting the lived
realities of our community. This project opened my eyes to the depth of systemic discrimination faced by people with disabilities
in my home country, but also showed me their incredible resilience and eagerness to learn when given
access to tools. It challenged me to think creatively about how to adapt when facing structural barriers,
and it inspired me to pursue design not only as a personal career path but also as a medium for
empowerment and social impact. “This project taught me that true empowerment isn't about giving people what we think they need, but
about listening to their realities and adapting to meet them with practical, tangible skills. It was a powerful
lesson in resilience and the transformative potential of a supportive community. By shifting our focus from
college preparation to tangible skills like 3D modeling, we learned to meet people where they are, giving
them the tools and confidence to build their own path forward.”

Title: AccessEd
Quote:
AccessEd created an online platform connecting Afghan girls with curated educational resources,
scholarship guidance, and mentorship opportunities. The project used a combination of a responsive
website, a 24/7 AI-powered chatbot, and anonymized mentorship sessions to provide safe and
continuous access to information for those barred from traditional schooling.
AccessEd was created in response to the shared reality of many Afghan girls whose education has been
severely restricted. Their stories and challenges informed every step of this project’s design, making it a
collective effort to build solutions for those who face systemic barriers.
In partnership with the nonprofit Applied Ethics, we developed an approach centered on privacy, ethical
storytelling, and building trust with participants. Each participant was given an anonymous nickname,
creating a safe space to engage freely. We hosted weekly workshops and meetings that introduced
participants to scholarship research, study skills, and digital literacy. Because participants came from
different educational backgrounds, I provided tailored resources and materials to help them stay engaged
and up to speed.  I define peace as the creation of conditions where individuals can thrive without fear, exclusion, or
systemic barriers. Peace is not simply the absence of conflict, it is the presence of opportunity, dignity,
and a sense of belonging.This project has profoundly changed how I think about technology and social impact. It showed me that building tools for vulnerable communities is not just a technical challenge, it is an ethical responsibility. I am leaving this experience with a deeper commitment to designing technology that protects users, builds
trust, and contributes to lasting change. More than anything, AccessEd has inspired me to continue
developing solutions that are not only innovative but also sustainable and just.

Title: Advancing Breast Cancer Care in Bangladesh
Advancing Environmental Justice through an Intergenerational Citizen Science Project
Quote: This project aimed to counter environmental inequity and promote planetary citizenship through intergenerational collaboration in the Praia Grande Quilombola community on Ilha de Maré, in the Bay of Todos os Santos, Brazil. By pairing young people with elders to co-create a recipe book and podcast, the project documented unique food traditions threatened by industrial expansion and environmental degradation, while advocating for the environmental, health, and cultural rights of traditional communities that continue to live in harmony with nature. My definition of peace has been inspired by the Indigenous Latin American philosophy of sumak kawsay or buen vivir (“good living”), which emphasizes harmony not only among human beings but also between humans and the natural world. Peace, in this sense, extends beyond the mere absence of conflict— it encompasses relational, ecological, and social balance, where communities and individuals can thrive together while respecting the environment. This project contributed to peace on multiple levels. In the short term, it created safe, collaborative spaces for dialogue and learning across generations. By pairing young people with elders through a mentor-apprenticeship model, participants developed mutual trust, strengthened social bonds, and reinforced respect for traditional knowledge. In the long term, the project seeks to preserve cultural heritage and environmental wisdom, empowering the community to assert their rights, sustain their food practices, and resist ecological injustice. By documenting and celebrating traditional food knowledge, the project promotes environmental stewardship and a sense of collective agency— foundations for lasting peace and resilience.

Title: AI Strengthening Healthcare Access (AISHA)
Quote:
We chose to address the lack of accessible, context-specific healthcare education for healthcare
workers in Sierra Leone. Limited access to training contributes to preventable deaths, high maternal and infant mortality, and weak systems for professional development. During earlier exploration, clinicians voiced frustration about gaps in knowledge and strong interest in more continuous, practical education. AISHA was designed to close this gap by combining trusted medical content with voice-powered conversational technology. AISHA delivers AI-powered voice devices to expand access to medical knowledge for healthcare workers in low-resource, connectivity-limited settings. These devices provide real-time answers, learning tools, quizzes, and patient simulations to strengthen decision-making and improve care delivery. Offline, interactive, and bilingual in English and Krio (in beta), it creates opportunities for active learning, especially for workers with limited literacy. In contrast to one-off trainings or static posters, AISHA provides ongoing, adaptable support that aligns with how people learn on the job.To us, peace is rooted in the commitment to uphold human rights, especially the right to health.
We encountered a significant conflict when faced with the decision to abandon Alexa and start over with custom devices. Months of work had gone into the Alexa version, but it could not function offline. Restarting from scratch was a difficult decision, but by prioritizing user realities, we demonstrated grit and adaptability. The result was a device ready in time for pilots, with enthusiastic uptake by clinicians. True peace is not just the absence of conflict but the presence of systems that ensure dignity, equity, and opportunity. Access to healthcare is a cornerstone of human well-being, and without it, the foundation of lasting peace is fragile.

Title: Another shore: start from zero (“Otra orilla: empezar de cero”)
Quote:
The project is a visual novel videogame titled “Another Shore: start from 0” and addresses the
relationship between migrant teens and Uruguayans at Uruguayan High Schools. The objective is to reach teenagers in a medium they are familiar with: videogames and thus fostering understanding with their migrant peers. The objective is to make an interactive experience which will
develop further discussions about their relationships. For me, peace is more than silence. It’s mutual respect, dignity, connection, and the everyday actions
that allow us to grow together without exclusion. In the short term, Another Shore gives students a
moment to walk in someone else’s shoes. In the long term, it has the potential to shape how students
build relationships.
"Creating Another Shore taught me that storytelling—especially through games—can be
a powerful tool to build empathy and start conversations about inclusion and belonging."

Title: Arte Vivo Archive: The Voices of Comuna 13
Quote:
Our team formed around shared connections to Latin American countries, specifically Honduras
and Mexico, which guided our decision to address human rights narratives in the region. Our academic
and personal interests focus on how art can serve as a tool for holistic well-being and joy when navigating
political, social, and economic difficulties. Given our collective experience with personal testimonials and
archiving, we wanted to explore how others use art for resilience and resistance within their own
communities. We decided to find a way to focus on human rights violations within Latin America,
specifically with the goal of highlighting how community members demonstrate resilience and find joy
while navigating histories of violence and personal loss.  The Arte Vivo Archive project addressed the discrepancies found in outside portrayals of
Medellín, Colombia by centering joy and resilience in our conversations surrounding human rights.
Through a partnership with Comuna Project, an international non-governmental organization (INGO), that
connected us to the local community of Comuna 13, we conducted community-centered interviews with
local artists. We created an interactive online map showcasing around 18 artists from diverse mediums,
stories which highlighted the transformation of a historic place of conflict into a site of joy, hope, and
peacebuilding.

Title: Breaking Bread, Building Belonging: Fostering Community, Food Justice, and a Vision for an Outdoor Kitchen
Quote:
Breaking Bread Building Belonging sought to address food insecurity in Irvington, a low-income
neighborhood in West Baltimore City, through the establishment of a Breakfast Program and the planning
and construction of a preliminary outdoor kitchen space. The project was purposefully rooted in an ethos
of community kinship and care, aiming to create open dialogue in which all community members have an
active say and voice in the construction of the outdoor space.
The beginnings of this project stemmed from interests in the Black Panther Party’s free Breakfast
program. As a young scholar and believer in forms of mutual aid, particularly within minoritized
communities, the breakfast program implemented by the Panthers reflected my interest in the nexus of
food, racial justice, and community scholarship. Having spent significant hours in the classroom, I wished
to expand my learning and see what it might look like to implement a breakfast program in my own
community, a community greatly impacted by structural racism and food insecurity. The community I grew
up in has always been one centered on mutual aid, so I found that being able to bring resources to my
community in the form of gathering over food and providing food allowed me to feel like a reciprocal
member of my community's spaces. The local relationships that developed out of this were incredible to
me, as many of the elders and neighbors on the block told me numerous times about how successful the
programming was, how delicious the breakfast was, and how it was such a joy to see the young people
eating breakfast and socializing with one another. I found older neighbors coming and bringing extra fruits
and vegetables they thought would pair well with whatever we were cooking that day. People were happy
to contribute extra paper plates, and some already wanted to use the grill. When we were building the
shed to store the equipment, many neighbors came to help or at least to chat and keep me company. “Breaking Bread Building Belonging taught me the power of small actions to make a world of difference.  
By sharing meals and building food infrastructure together, I learned that peacebuilding begins with
community care, listening, and creating spaces where everyone’s voice matters.”

Title: Breaking the Silence on Menstruation in Nepal
Quote:
My project, Breaking the Silence on Menstruation in Nepal, addressed menstrual stigma and lack of
access to safe, sustainable menstrual products. By working with Blink Foundation, Loom Nepal, and GET
Nepal, I implemented workshops in four schools, distributed menstrual kits, and fostered peer mentorship
programs to normalize open conversations about menstruation. While I initially envisioned broader distribution, I adjusted the project’s scale to focus on building a
model in fewer schools. This allowed for deeper engagement, stronger training, and better feedback
collection. An unexpected outcome was that the organizations I partnered with, who had not previously
included menstrual health in their programming, expressed interest in continuing this work after seeing
the impact and demand. This creates opportunities for long-term sustainability.
Reflection
To me, peace means the freedom to live with confidence, access opportunities, and make choices without
barriers. Menstrual stigma becomes a barrier to these freedoms by forcing girls to miss school, lowering
their confidence, and reinforcing inequality. By providing resources and safe spaces for dialogue, my
project aimed to open doors for greater equality and dignity.

Title: Bridging Divides: Reviving Unity and Peace in Kakuma Refugee Camp
Quote:
This initiative addressed the longstanding intertribal conflict between the Dinka and Nuer communities in
Kakuma Refugee Camp by training peace delegates, organizing a large-scale peace conference, and
establishing sustainable mechanisms for reconciliation. Through dialogue, mentorship, and symbolic
activities like a football match, the project restored trust, fostered unity, and empowered local leaders to
continue peacebuilding efforts beyond the program.
At the start of the project, the number I had in mind was 45 delegates for a 7 day training. However, the overwhelming urge of everyone wanting to join and make a difference made us increase the number to 300 youth and
community leaders from both tribes. Gender and disability inclusion were prioritized in the selection,
which was conducted through interviews. Once admitted, delegates underwent training in mediation, negotiation, and cultural understanding. The next stage was a seven day Community Peace Conference, which was originally projected to host 450 participants, but the desire of community members to
take part led us to accommodate 800 delegates. The weeklong conference featured
lively discussions and skill-sharing workshops. Cultural activities which are common to both communities
like ‘Kabulo’ and ‘Liro’ were central to the event, and a symbolic football match between Dinka’s Koryom
Boys and Nuer’s Bentiu Boys drew over 2,000 spectators, with families sharing side by side. The match
demonstrated unity in action, and spontaneous community contributions—such as drinks and chairs
donated by local business persons—reflected local ownership and enthusiasm.
For one month following the conference, delegates applied their skills to mediate disputes in their neighborhoods while we did the monitoring. A two-day follow-up conference that allowed participants to evaluate progress, address new challenges, and designate official Peace Ambassadors.The two days were mostly run by the delegates themselves while being guided by the project managers, and they
shared with us all the great things they had accomplished during the one-month implementation.
Ambassadors were awarded certificates. My next aim is to build a youth center since a foundation for
peace has been achieved. To me, peace is the courage to heal from wounds of war, the willingness to embrace one another as one
people, and the commitment to create trust and belonging. In Kakuma, peace means dismantling the
barriers that political forces once weaponized and building compassion, trust, and shared belonging.
In the short term, the project gave delegates practical skills, created platforms for dialogue, and sparked
hope across the camp. In the long term, it established peace ambassadors who can sustain reconciliation
efforts within their communities. The project’s greatest value lies in the structures it created—institutions
of trust that will endure beyond my involvement.  This project has shown me that peace is the courage to turn division into unity. By reconnecting the Dinka
and Nuer in Kakuma, we proved that reconciliation is possible even under the weight of history.

Title: Bridging issei and us through a picture-sound book
Quote:
Our project involved the creation of a picture book with the addition of 3D printing and audio elements that supplemented the book. The topic of the book is the incarceration camps of Japanese Americans and Americans of Japanese descent, specifically at the Minidoka location, where many Portland-based people went. The purpose of the book is to preserve the voices and stories of survivors, educate the younger generations on this neglected history, and inspire peace in our present global climate. 
We had the rare opportunity of meeting and interviewing two survivors of the camp whose stories we based the book on. From the beginning of this project's conception, our perception of the world had already begun to
change. We were shocked to find out that people of Japanese descent were put into incarceration camps during World War II. We were not taught the horrors of the event and how it impacted the civilians who
were placed in these camps. From this point, we realized the selective nature of education and
discovered the flaws of the world. Additionally, we learned that the selective incarceration of ethnic
Italians and Germans also occurred in Japan during wartime. The existence of incarceration camps in
Japan speaks to the fact that racial discrimination is not an issue specific to America but an issue of fear
breeding injustice, dehumanization, othering, and selectiveness of historical memory. We recognize that
this is a pattern of history that must stop, yet continues to happen time and time again.

Title: Bridging Relationships, Building Peace: Counseling for Marital Harmony
Quote:
This project taught us that peace comes from the economic and social freedom to build a dignified life.
When women in under-resourced communities gain the skills and support to lead businesses, they
transform not just their lives but the possibilities for everyone around them. Our project addressed barriers to women’s economic participation in Lahore by launching a women-centered incubation lab that offered training, mentorship, and an inclusive space for growth. Over five
weeks, the program worked with 32 women micro-entrepreneurs who strengthened their business skills,
built peer networks, and launched ventures that boosted both their confidence and their communities. Our project addressed barriers to women’s economic participation in Lahore by launching a women-
centered incubation lab that offered training, mentorship, and an inclusive space for growth. Over fiveweeks, the program worked with 32 women micro-entrepreneurs who strengthened their business skills,
built peer networks, and launched ventures that boosted both their confidence and their communities.  Early sessions focused on trust-
building, mapping personal motivations, and defining success beyond income. Participants then developed product and service offerings, practiced pitching their ideas, and built digital storefronts. Live clinics with
our lead trainer turned nerves into momentum, helping participants translate skills into market-ready ventures. Adjustments were made along the way to accommodate varied digital literacy and
space constraints, including one-on-one coaching and flexible use of the training hall. Graduation on August 30 was a powerful celebration of the cohort’s achievements. With certificates in hand,
participants took their places at mini-demo booths, sharing their ventures and receiving public
acknowledgment from mentors, family, and peers. They left with tested business models, live digital
storefronts, and the beginnings of their customer networks, but also with something more: a tangible key to
their future. The early outcomes are already clear, with increased income-generation activities, a strong
sense of entrepreneurial confidence, and a lasting foundation of peer-supported accountability.

Title: Building Peace Through Art and Storytelling
Quote:
I wrote a children’s book with 32 primary students in Arusha, Tanzania, as part of a peace
education program that combined storytelling, art, and mental health awareness to help children develop
empathy, resilience, and conflict resolution skills.  Over the course of the program, students created stories and artwork that
were later compiled into a book, celebrating their voices and perspectives.
We printed a reasonable amount of copies that we needed for the training including those from
Peace Education Foundation such as Peacemaking Skills for Little Kids, PreK/K - Digital Teacher's Guide,
Creative Conflict Solving for Kids, Grades 3-4 - Digital Teacher's Guide, Peace Scholars: Creative Conflict
Solving, Grade 5 - Digital Teacher's and digital versions were shared with schools and community
partners to extend the project’s reach and enable them to utilize the materials for future training that they
will work on. The book compilation was completed and printed by a local printing enterprise in Tanzania.
I chose to focus on peace education because children in Tanzania, like in many parts of the
world, have little understanding of peace and how they can play a vital role in resolving conflicts at their
community level. I believe that introducing peace concepts early can provide young people with tools for
resilience and community building on the grounds of fairness and equity.
Arusha was selected because of my partnership with the School of St. Jude and Changemakers
Foundation, all of which provided space, staff, and community connections. These organizations played
vital roles, they offered facilitators, recruited students, and helped ensure that the program was integrated
into school and will help promote our work to the broader community including distributing the printed
books.This project inspired me to see peace not as an abstract idea but as something built moment by
moment, through children’s stories, through their drawings, and through their willingness to learn from one
another. I now understand more clearly that a peaceful future is one where every child is given the tools
and opportunities to become a peacemaker in their own community.
“Through this project, I realized that peace begins with listening to children’s voices. When we
give them the tools to imagine and create, they quickly become powerful advocates for a more
compassionate and peaceful world.”

Title: Building Peace Through Water Supply
Quote:
This initiative sought to advance peace and equity in Bhaluwai village, Sindhuli, Nepal by addressing
caste-based water discrimination that denied Dalits access to clean water. The project involved building
six communal taps in the Dalit settlement, connected through pipelines from Raage village. By ensuring
reliable water access, the project reduced tensions between castes, eliminated the need for Dalits to use
restricted taps, and promoted dignity and health. The work was carried out in partnership with the Udaan
Foundation, with approval from the Ward 1 government authorities, and in collaboration with a contracted
plumbing team from Bardibas.  For this project, peace was not defined as immediate integration of castes at the same water source.
Instead, peace meant reducing conflict and violence by ensuring that Dalits had their own secure water
supply. Thus, peace is a process rather than a single moment. This practical approach created dignity
and safety for Dalits, while opening the door for future dialogue toward deeper social integration.

The project revealed how reality often diverges from written proposals. Unexpected conflicts,
absenteeism, and adminitrative delays forced quick adaptation. For example, I had to lead and direct online. With time difference and bureaucratic delays, I had to learn to be
patient and consistent with my efforts. Later, I redirected funds meant for my travel to construct a
bathroom and a seating structure near the taps, allowing people to rest and enjoy fresh water together.
These improvisations reminded me the importance of resilience and flexibility.

Title: Building Peace, One Venture at a Time in Rural Kenya
Quote:
“This project cemented in me the belief that peace begins with opportunity. By
equipping young people with entrepreneurial skills and resources, we give them hope, agency, and a
pathway to transform their futures.To make this vision possible, I
worked with Centonomy to train three teachers who will manage the center and guide students in
developing their ventures. The project also equipped the center with 15 computers, Wi-Fi access for the
first time in the school’s history, a comprehensive entrepreneurship curriculum, and a subscription to
Business Daily to expose students to current market dynamics and business news.

Title: Burushal Sports Academy: Women Empowerment Through Soccer
Quote:
Our project, in collaboration with the Burushal (or: Brooshal) Sports Academy (BSA), aimed to
challenge gender inequality in Yasin, Northern Pakistan, by empowering girls through soccer. In summer 2025, we successfully registered the Academy with the Pakistani Government, conducted a pilot training
camp, started our website building, and purchased land for the Academy. This collaboration laid the
foundation for a resilient and sustainable institution that can continue to grow despite environmental
challenges such as flooding, while advancing gender justice in the region, and taught us to embrace
uncertainty, innovate, and adapt to changing circumstances.
The project was inspired by the backlash against the creation of
the first women’s soccer club in Yasin Valley, which went viral on local media. As best friends from across
the India-Pakistan border, we recognized that the skills and abilities we learned during our time in UWC
and beyond had empowered us to become catalysts for positive change. 
By supporting and working together with the BSA, we sought to establish a sustainable, inclusive space
for young women to participate and challenge dominant, deep-rooted social norms and perceptions.  Outcomes included
1. Flood-Resilient Infrastructure: The land purchase secured a safe, elevated space for the
Academy, protecting it from disasters that destroyed many local facilities.
2. Direct Participation: A pilot camp brought together girls for training and confidence-building,
marking a step forward in community acceptance of women’s sports.
3. Institutional Growth: The Academy is now formally registered, providing legitimacy, recognition,
and a pathway for future expansion.
4. Digital Advocacy: As the region recovers from floods, we are developing a website and
launching a social media campaign to challenge cultural norms, spread awareness, and gather
broader support for the Academy.

Title: Cervicare for Peace: A path to health and lasting unity for Kayayei in Ghana
Quote:
This project addressed the dual issues of health inequity and peacebuilding among Kayayei (female head
porters) in Accra, Ghana, by providing cervical cancer screening, reproductive health education, peer
educator training, and an avenue for peace dialogue. We collaborated with the Zongo Care Initiative,
Kayayei, local health facilities, and the Kayayei Youth Association to provide screening services and
facilitate peace dialogues that strengthened solidarity among the women from diverse ethnic
backgrounds.

Title: Chhori Ka Paila (The footprints of a daughter)
Quote:
This project addressed the issues of period stigma, lack of sanitation, and gender inequality in
rural Nepal by building 12 school toilets, delivering menstrual health workshops for 900+ students,
and training 57 women to produce reusable sanitary pads. The project was implemented in
collaboration with United World Schools (UWS) Nepal, the local government of Sankhuwasabha, and
supported by the Davis Projects for Peace grant. We selected the issue of menstrual health and education because it remains one of the most persistent barriers to gender equality in Nepal. In Sankhuwasabha, menstruation is still stigmatized, and girls
often miss school or drop out entirely due to the lack of resources and safe facilities.  “Something that impacted me the most was seeing the boys in the class taking the lead in reminding
their classmates about period awareness. When one person participated, slowly, people who were too
shy to talk about it also started opening up. This showed me how change is possible when the entire
community is involved. Additionally, it reminded all of us that peace isn't just about putting a stop to
conflict; it is about developing as a community to make life better and more comfortable for everyone
living in it.” – Prakriti Manandhar

Members:
Kajol Luplunge
Aslesha Shrestha, Clark University 
Gaurav Pradhan, United World College Costa Rica

Title: Code Her Future: Empowering Girls in Tech in Tamale
Quote:
This summer, I implemented “Code Her Future” at the Evangelical Church of Ghana School Complex
in Tamale. The project addressed the systemic barriers facing girls in STEM education by introducing
a tailored curriculum in coding, digital literacy, and problem-solving, while also engaging parents, local
teachers, and local leaders to dismantle cultural barriers and build a sustainable pathway for girls into
technology, fostering a more equitable and innovative community. My decision on the issue to address was rooted in a lifetime of observing the stark educational
inequities in Northern Ghana. I saw brilliant, curious girls like my sisters systematically steered away
from technical fields due to a lack of resources, representation, and deeply ingrained cultural norms.
The approach was twofold: first, to provide direct, hands-on skill-building for the girls to demystify
technology and build confidence; and second, to orchestrate a parallel community engagement
strategy. I knew that without winning the trust and support of parents and local educators, any
technical skills taught would be short-lived. Therefore, the strategy was intentionally holistic, targeting
not just the students but the entire ecosystem that influences their educational choices. the most impactful sessions came from two unexpected
sources: a young female app developer from Accra who joined via Zoom for a short while, and a
female agricultural science student from UDS who demonstrated how she uses data analysis to
improve crop yields. This real-world, Ghanaian-centric application of STEM was more powerful than I
had anticipated, so I pivoted to source more local and relatable role models. For me, peace is not only the absence of violence or conflict—it is the active presence of opportunity,
dignity, and inclusion. When girls are denied access to education, especially in fields like STEM that
shape the future, their exclusion perpetuates cycles of inequality that destabilize families and
communities. By creating spaces where girls could see themselves as capable engineers and
problem-solvers, the project planted seeds of peace that I believe will grow both individually and
collectively. One father told me, "I always thought this was for boys in the big cities. Now I see my
daughter can do it too." This dismantling of a prejudicial belief is a direct act of building peace.

Title: Community Greenhouse - Climate Adaptive Mountain Vegetable Farming
Quote:
This project, in Ghami, Upper
Mustang, Nepal, addressed community food insecurity and lack of access to fresh vegetables during
harsh winters. By building a greenhouse with the Ama Soma Mothers’ Club and local partners, the
project created a sustainable solution that empowers women, strengthens community ties, and improves
nutrition. I chose to address the issue of nutrition deficiency and food insecurity in Ghami,
where families often survive on barley, buckwheat, and potatoes for months due to heavy snow and travel
restrictions. The lack of dietary variety has long-term impacts on health, particularly for children and
mothers. The physical project building process lasted a total of two weeks, including travel
from Kathmandu to Ghami. The greenhouse itself was constructed over 10 days of active building. The
workforce combined local skills and community engagement: 10 workers in total contributed, including 7
members of the Ama Soma Mothers’ Club, 3 local villagers with construction experience, and the local
building expert, Jayang Khetuk. Community members carried stones, prepared mud, and supported the
labor effort, while mothers took on both physical and organizational roles to ensure progress remained on
track. The mayor of the rural municipality also joined the celebration at the project’s completion,
underscoring the local government’s recognition and support. In all, the project represented a genuine
collaboration between villagers, leaders, and skilled builders, reinforcing community ownership of the
greenhouse.  One conflict we faced was the physical strain of carrying stones, which tested everyone’s strength and
patience. The work was exhausting, especially in the thin mountain air, and at times it felt overwhelming.
But rather than allowing this to create frustration, we turned it into a shared challenge. We rotated tasks,
encouraged one another, and even turned breaks into mini-celebrations with food, laughter, and music.
This reminded me that conflict is not always about disagreement—it can also be about hardship, and the
way people respond to hardship can either divide or unite them. In this case, it became a source of
solidarity."Building the greenhouse in my hometown of Ghami showed me that peace begins with meeting simple
human needs like food security. Working with the Ama Soma Mothers’ Club taught me that true resilience
and sustainability come from empowering local communities to take ownership. This project has not only
given my village hope for the winters ahead, but has also shaped how I view the meaning of peace in
practice."

Title: Confronting the Ongoing Environmental Legacy of Nuclear Tests in the Marshall Islands
Quote:
Peace is not just about creating a world without conflict, it is about addressing the long lasting remnants
of past injustices and the effects they have on communities. The way in which radioactive contamination
spreads from fallout and sediments to living organisms is an important ecological topic that has been
recognized both among the scientific community and beyond, specifically through the Treaty on the
Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW), which requires environmental remediation and assistance for
victims of nuclear weapons tests.In a time of global unrest with wars in Europe and the Middle East, conversations surrounding nuclear
weapons have attracted a new wave of attention. While luckily no residual radiation has been found in fish
from the Kwajalein Atoll, this project helps confront and bring attention to the often overlooked long term
consequences, such as contamination, from nuclear weapons, which can last for centuries and have
serious and widespread health impacts. In a world where a nuclear war has become much more of a
distinct possibility, this project aimed to emphasize that it is our collective responsibility to ensure the
health and wellbeing of all communities, especially those that are marginalized or overlooked, and to hold
world powers accountable for their actions.

Title:
Connecting Threads: Reciprocity and Gratitude as Pedagogies of Peace in
Oaxacan Textile
Quote:
Peace is the active and continuous presence of justice, respect, and equity which is nurtured
through communal cycles of reciprocity and gratitude where every individual contributes and has a sense
of belonging and purpose. The traditional practices of natural dyeing and weaving in Teotitlán del Valle
embody this vision of peace by fostering intergenerational relationships rooted in patience, reciprocity,
and care. Participating in this project was the most rewarding experience of my life as it nurtured my growth as an
organizer, an educator, a student, and a human being. My interest in Oaxacan textiles began from an
academic and research-based perspective, as well as an artistic curiosity to understand how textile
practices withstand periods of conflict and erasure through nurturing connections across generations,
spaces, and even species. The artistic and ecological community engagement at the heart of this project
gave me firsthand insight into the values that sustain these ancient traditions, and how they, in turn,
sustain peace within the community.

Title: Creativity in Action: Integrated Arts in Grassroots Organizing
Quote:
Oftentimes, the arts and culture are sidelined in the work of political mobilization and organizing. But art –
the very process of creation – has been transformative for the very reasons it is overlooked. Creating
together asks for a social dreaming-of, and dreaming-up, that is based on and grounds us in the real
worlds we live in. Creativity in Action is a grassroots organizing effort that enlists socially engaged art practices to address
the socio-ecological disruption faced by campesino communities in Norcasia, Caldas, after the
construction of a megadam in the region. Through collaborative workshops, cultural programming, and
collaborative filmmaking, the integrated arts project has encouraged dialogue and reflection on water
insecurity and displacement, inviting communities from three villages to participate in an exercise of
collective remembering.   For the past three months, my definition of peace for this project has remained largely the same – it is and
has been a process of regeneration and healing through and beyond conflict, be it through community
screenings or extended interviews with individuals. Beyond situating community members within
self-made narratives and histories that affirm their own experiences of conflict, displacement, and water
scarcity, these past few months of assisting documentation efforts have also situated me as an
intermediary between this reality that is urgent, complex, and disjointed, and realities I have had the
fortunate opportunity to peek into during my education in the Global North, realities defined by
convenience and comfort. The idea of peace as regenerative is not necessarily a passive one. I believe
that regeneration is necessary work for grassroots organizing – political processes, no matter how big or
small, require the unity and consensus of its collective. What I hope we have done through this project is
strengthen the foundation for such processes of positive change.

Title: Cuidando Juntos: Empowering Women's Health Through Cervical Cancer Prevention
Quote:
This project implemented mobile cervical cancer prevention campaigns across 11 cities in four provinces, reaching 500 patients, and integrating culturally sensitive education, community collaboration, and accessible screening and treatment services in partnership with Partners for Andean Community Health (PACH), Hospital FIBUSPAM in Riobamba (Chimborazo province), Indigenous leaders, and community health workers. Through interviews with healthcare professionals, community leaders, and
patients, I identified key barriers faced by rural and Indigenous communities. These insights, combined
with national data showing high incidence and mortality rates due to cervical cancer, informed the design
of a three-part program: (1) community education and engagement, (2) screening and treatment, and (3)
follow-up care. Through conversations with community leaders and patients, I knew that culturally tailored
educational materials in Spanish and Kichwa were essential. My project contributes to peace by bridging the
gap between Western and traditional medicine through deep listening and collaboration with community
health leaders, local doctors, and residents. By creating dialogue and understanding where mistrust
originates, how it has been shaped over time, and how communities perceive healthcare, we sought to
co-create solutions rather than impose them. This approach strengthens relationships, empowers
communities to take charge of their health outcomes, and lays the foundation for long-term peace and
equitable healthcare.Additionally, the project enabled women to take ownership of their own health. This empowerment is, in my eyes, an expression of peace. “Implementing this project showed me that sustainable change begins with co-creating solutions.
By combining culturally grounded education with accessible screening, treatment, and follow-up care, we
helped women reclaim ownership of their health in underserved communities–and yet there is still so
much more to do. Ecuador has become a second home to me, and I am committed to returning to
continue and expand this work!”

Title: Cultivating Community: Transforming the Jonquil Hotel Courtyard
Quote:
My project renovated the neglected courtyard of a Chicago homeless shelter and transformed it into a
vibrant, safe, and inviting community space. My approach was to design and implement a courtyard renovation at Good News Partners’ Jonquil Hotel, a shelter for women and families in Rogers Park. The project created a basketball playing area, picnic
benches and a grill for shared meals, a bike rack stocked with refurbished bicycles, and a tile art project
created by shelter residents. Each element was chosen with input from residents, ensuring the courtyard
reflected their priorities rather than an outside vision imposed on them. By inviting residents to co-create
and lead the renovation process, I sought to foster ownership of the space and empower residents as
community builders.  I define peace as the ability of people to live with dignity in community with one another,
supported by spaces that foster connection, joy, and mutual care. Peace is not only the absence of
conflict but the presence of belonging.
 In the short term, the project immediately reduced
isolation. Children now ride bikes together after school; teenagers gather for pickup basketball games;
adults sit at picnic tables to talk, cook, and eat. In the long term, the courtyard will contribute to peace by
fostering community life in tangible, everyday ways.
This project stretched me as a leader. I managed construction logistics,
coordinated volunteers, mediated conflicts, and built relationships across nonprofit and community
partners. There were days when I was mounting benches in the sun, others when I was examining budget
reallocations, and still others when I was facilitating childcare while paint dried nearby. Each challenge
deepened my confidence in myself and my abilities.
In addition, this project taught me the importance of reintroducing beauty and dignity into people’s lives.
Too often, responses to homelessness focus only on meeting basic needs like food and shelter. While
these are essential, people also deserve spaces that are uplifting, peaceful, and beautiful.

Title: Cultivating Harmony: Empowering Indigenous Communities Through Conflict Management and Sustainable Resource Practices
Quote:
This  project addressed conflict resolution, effective communication for favourable
outcomes, and resource management within Indigenous communities in Malaysia through a combination
of data collection, capacity-building workshops, and partnership development. We worked directly with community leaders, villagers, and
relevant stakeholders to strengthen inter-village ties and collaboration, while also equipping participants
with the skills and confidence to engage constructively with external stakeholders. While the proposal included land rights research, we found these issues to be complex, politicised, and
requiring expertise beyond our team’s capacity. Direct involvement risked creating sensitivities or
jeopardising access to communities. Instead, we focused on strengthening communication and
collaboration skills, enabling communities to problem-solve internally and engage constructively with
stakeholders already working on land rights. Similarly, although formal partnerships with government and
NGOs were envisioned, time and resource constraints led us to prioritise intra- and inter-village
collaboration, laying a foundation for future advocacy and partnerships.The experience reminded us that peacebuilding requires humility, patience, and cultural sensitivity. It also
challenged us to balance ambition with realism, redirecting our efforts from complex land issues to areas
where we could make meaningful contributions. Small actions like cross-village networking or safe spaces
for dialogue proved powerful in sparking collaboration.
Ultimately, the project inspired us to continue using training and capacity-building as tools for peace,
reinforcing that peace is not a destination but an ongoing process of relationship-building, respect, and
resilience.

Title: CWRU Humanitarian Design Corps Malawi
Quote:
This project was to design and install a solar microgrid in the remote ranger camp of Miondwe in
Kasungu National Park in Malawi for 6 rangers and their families as well as a provision for a solar power
borehole pump. Our definition of peace is the environment where citizens of
the world are able to comfortably live in their land without threat to their lives. The environment where the
individuals feel safe and respected from the social and economic group they belong to.

Title: DigiAccess (Previously Flavors for Peace)
Quote:
We set out to empower disadvantaged groups in India with skills and training to increase their earning potential.
However, early on we found that the highly competitive low-income job market in India is highly inelastic
and therefore marginal income growth from investment into formal training would not have incrementally
positive return. For this reason, we looked for ideas with a similar ethos of increasing skills and earning
potential while adding a constraint of providing a high return on funding investment. Using the idiom “give
a man a fish, he eats for a day, teach them to fish, they eat forever” as inspiration, we organized a 2 week
long hackathon-like competition. With technology being the preeminent tool of our time, the focus of our
competition is to get students to envision how technology can be used to create solutions that solve
contemporary problems at large and within their local communities.
By partnering with Airtel Foundation’s schools’ arm we were
able to bring together 64 students from 7 schools in Punjab to work in teams of up to 5 to envision tech-power solutions. The students in the process were able to learn about key technology capabilities including basics, the internet and AI whilst also developing their problem solving and communication skills. We are very happy with the volume of participation and most important the quality of the ideas generated by the students
validated that incredible potential is being constrained simply due to a lack of access to infrastructure. Seeing students create fully fledged prototypes such as video games, tech-powered sanitation solutions and bicycle safety solutions was invigorating. With the successful orchestration of the competition and distribution of devices, we believe that this
concept is a validated form of driving mobility and peace in the world.

Title: Discovery in Action: Enhancing STEM Education for Underprivileged High School Students in Preveza, Greece
Quote:
The team worked with teachers, administrators and the parent associations at the Preveza Music School
in Preveza, Greece to address the lack of resources for STEM education and opportunities at the school.
Working with these stakeholders, we co-designed the lab, acquired materials and equipment for the lab,
created draft curricula to guide how the materials can be used in a class setting, and organized
workshops to ensure successful uptake and engagement with the lab. In the short term, we
strengthened connections with the Preveza community and with the Music School, and we launched a
science lab that will allow young people to pursue expanded pathways. For some individuals, this may be
a spark that allows them to truly thrive in their lives, and possibly find career paths that align with them.
Being able to offer a more rounded curriculum at the Music School will also allow the school to support
students more fully. We hope this creates a virtuous cycle where students in the community find success
through opportunities that go beyond their music. We also hope that the project over the long term will
help foster science, knowledge and understanding that contributes positively to society. This project showed us that minor inefficiencies can pile up to become structural barriers that truly inhibit
the ability of some communities to acquire the opportunities that others have. Bureaucratic approvals,
oftentimes contradicting from one entity to another, lead to huge wait times for the deliveries. We saw this
when banking policy contradicted WPI’s ordering policy, which contradicted the tariffs imposed by the US
government, which affected our project budget – the friction caused by the accumulated inefficiencies and
contradictions gave us a first hand view of what it looks like to try to overcome global inequalities.
Science is not the information written in books and on white boards, but the understanding and utilization
of the natural world around us, something remarkable, resembling magic even to the most knowledgeable
of people. Making sure the younger generations understand this is a key to ensuring a brighter and
sustainable future that can harbor well-being, growth, and peace.-

Title: Documenting Stories of Syrian Prison Survivors
Quote:
This project documented the story of Omar Alshogre, a survivor of Assad’s Saydnaya Prison, through a
short documentary film combining interviews, archival materials, and artistic collaborations. The project
raised awareness of Syrian prison survivors, engaged local and international communities through a
movie screening and discussions, and laid the groundwork for launching a nonprofit, Beyond Saydnaya,
to provide long-term support to survivors.Working on this project taught me that peace begins when survivors’ voices are heard, validated, and
supported. Documenting Omar’s story was a powerful first step, but the real work extends beyond a
single narrative—it means ensuring that thousands of others like him, whose experiences have been
silenced, are remembered and given the resources to heal.
I learned that telling a story is not enough; it must be paired with action, advocacy, and community
engagement to create change. This project deepened my understanding that peace requires more than
the end of violence—it demands structures of care and accountability that honor survivors’ experiences.
Ultimately, this experience showed me that peace is relational, ongoing, and active. Even small efforts—a
documentary, a screening, a conversation—can spark broader awareness and action. True peace is
inseparable from empathy, advocacy, and sustained care.

Title: Echoes of Peace: Reconciliation of the Youth, for the Youth, by the Youth
Quote:
Echoes of a Peace was a 10-day class offered at the Idebate summer camp where students from all over
the country learned about Rwanda's Peace and Reconciliation Journey since the 1994 Genocide against
the Tutsi. As the youth were born post-genocide, there is a growing issue of misinformation, lack of
awareness, genocide denial, and revisionism. Hence, through academic books, guest speakers, field
trips, and their "Peace Projects,” students learned in-depth about Rwanda's peace process.  After this project, I am reminded of my belief that peace is a societal decision to heal and rebuild, one that
must be intergenerational and include post-conflict generations to ensure that violence does not resurface
and that stability is sustainable. Overall, this project has made me deeply value the perspectives and knowledge production of youth. I was genuinely impressed by their peace projects and the level of detail, thoughtfulness, and creativity they demonstrated. When developing policy solutions, we rarely consult or refer to youth, yet some of
their project ideas demonstrated such remarkable critical thinking and creativity that they merit serious
consideration.

I have always wanted to return to my country and empower youth at home. When I observed the rise of
online ethnic tensions linked to the conflict in Congo, I recognized the urgent need to raise awareness
about Rwanda’s peace and reconciliation journey. This project was particularly valuable because it
reminded youth that peace is not a static achievement but an intergenerational effort. I am convinced that
this project represents a meaningful step toward creating a lasting echo of peace in Rwanda, one that will
continue to resonate for generations to come.

Title: EcoEcho: Improving Equitable Outdoor Access for Vulnerable Children and People With Disabilities
Quote:
This project has revealed a lot of realistic aspects of nonprofit work that I have never encountered
previously. First, flexibility is essential. Plans rarely unfold exactly as intended, and that’s okay. As
long as the goal is ultimately achieved, there can be many paths and timelines to reach it. Another
reality is that not everyone will share the same sense of urgency or empathy for the issues you care
about.Hoping that EcoEcho’s workshops and environmental education curricula would foster new
relationships between vulnerable children and nature, I have witnessed both inspiring connections
and significant implementation challenges. These experiences have shown me that with sufficient
guidance and thoughtful facilitation, children and families can develop greater interest in the outdoors
and experience its physical and mental health benefits. Most importantly, this journey continues to
motivate me to seek realistic and impactful solutions that support the marginalized communities I care
deeply about.

Title: Educational Workshops on Animal Welfare and Environmentalism
Quote:
Humanity is at war with the planet. Metropolitan cities are rapidly developing
without proper environmental precautions and awareness among citizens. Deforestation, rapid
urbanization, and moral disregard for other species are prevailing local issues to name a few.The most complete definition of Peace is one that includes harmony between Humanity, Nature, and
other Species. If speciesism (the assumption of human superiority) is eliminated, it sets the ideal
foundation for peaceful coexistence with nature. Urban development and conservation can coexist, with
appropriate education and awareness among the youth! [We] conducted Educational Workshops focusing on Animal Welfare in 7 high schools in Bangalore, India. The workshops included interactive presentations, plant-based snacks, and field trips to animal shelters.  The short-term goals are such students may become more integral parts of their local community, engaging in volunteering/community-uplifting activities. The
longer-term goal is that such individuals go on to further bring a positive impact on their local
communities’ environmental, conservation, and animal welfare problems. The short-term goals are
already visible, with students reaching out to us for internship opportunities, connecting with shelters for
volunteering, teachers inviting us to continue this partnership yearly, etc!

Title: Empower Them
Quote:
Our project addressed domestic violence in Gateko village by empowering 30 women survivors with
female pigs and a week-long training in conflict resolution andentrepreneurship.Too me, peace means safety, dignity, and choice, especially for women who have been denied these basics through abuse or poverty. Our project helped restore peace by addressing the economic and emotional vulnerabilities that make women susceptible to domestic violence. Providing pigs, yes, but more importantly, providing voice, skills, and solidarity. That is the peace we built together in Gateko. The most difficult moment came during the selection of participants. Some community members who were not chosen felt left out, causing tension that could have jeopardized trust in the project. We quickly responded by openly sharing our selection criteria and emphasizing that every family would eventually benefit through the piglet-sharing model. I learned that transparency and humility are essential when working with vulnerable populations. Conflict can be resolved not just through theory, but through action, empathy, and inclusion.
Before this project, I thought of peace as a lofty concept tied to big political change. But I now understand peace as something personal and local. A woman with a pig, new skills, and a supportive group can shift the trajectory of her family. That ripple effect is real. This project affirmed to me that peace is rooted in justice, opportunity, and the empowerment of women.

Title: Empowered to Thrive: A Socio-Economic Reintegration Project for Displaced Women
Quote:
I chose to focus on displaced women and girls in Ouahigouya because displacement in northern
Burkina Faso has uprooted families and stripped women of stability, dignity, and opportunities for
self-sufficiency. Having grown up seeing the resilience of women in my community, I wanted to
design a project that would meet both their economic and emotional needs. Empowered to Thrive
combined skills training in gardening, goat-rearing, and weaving with psychosocial support. This
approach enabled women to rebuild their livelihoods while also finding space to process the
trauma of displacement. For displaced women in Burkina Faso, peace is not abstract. It means being able to feed their
families, to have their voices heard, and to remain rooted in community despite the fractures
caused by violence. A goat, a garden, or a weaving circle is more than just a source of livelihood; it
is a way to reclaim dignity, visibility, and belonging.  This project was not only a local initiative but a gesture of love, memory, and engagement for the
Africa we want; an Africa where women are not only helped, but also listened to and placed in the
spotlight as leaders of their own futures. Through Empowered to Thrive, I learned that peace is
built in small, practical acts that restore dignity: a goat, a garden, or a weaving circle can open
doors for women to reclaim their voices and their place in the community. Our idea of development
does not have to look western, we go a long way acknowledging what we actually need at the
moment.

Title: Empowering Education and Community Resilience in the Chittagong Hill Tracts
Quote: I see peace as the freedom to exist as who you are in any condition, with security, dignity, the ability to choose, and the opportunity for people to coexist respectfully. For the Indigenous children, peace is the ability to live without displacement and marginalization. This project contributes to peace by creating the access and opportunity an individual needs to find peace. It created a safe and supportive environment where Indigenous children can access education, a fundamental tool for empowerment and self-determination.  This project restored access to education for Indigenous children in the flood-affected Chengi Ideal School in the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT) in Khagrachari, Bangladesh, by rebuilding student dormitories, introducing eco-friendly transportation and supplying school materials for 147 students and 17 teachers. The project was implemented collaboratively with local leaders, school officials, and Indigenous diaspora community.  Home to over 54 Indigenous groups totaling approximately 1.65 million people, the CHT remains one of the most marginalized regions of Bangladesh, a situation worsened by 1980s settlement policies that displaced Indigenous communities from their land. The region also faces heightened vulnerability to climate change, where frequent flash floods and extreme weather further threaten already fragile infrastructure. The project addressed the urgent need to restore education for Indigenous children in the CHT, where systemic exclusion and climate-related vulnerabilities limit access to schooling. The short-term approaches included rebuilding infrastructure and providing essential educational resources to ensure continuity of learning, while the long-term approach focused on sustaining transportation and dormitory facilities to enable students from remote areas to attend school.

Title: Empowering Egyptian Women Through Community Automobile Education and Ride-sharing
Quote:
Our approach to tackling the issues of sexual harassment within transportation in Egypt was to
empower a community of women to both drive together and gain the necessary skills to repair their own
car. My project transformed the way I think about the world because I was able to see how strongly
the women were excited to learn about car repair. While this deeply inspired me, it also made me think
more about ways in which women are given less opportunities than men in terms of their own mobility
and ways to build their own sense of agency. This project showed to me that peace is about bringing
people together to accomplish something new and providing opportunities to people that wouldn’t have
otherwise been possible.

Title: Empowering Futures – From the Basketball Court to the Workforce
Quote:
The goal of this project was to teach low-income young Brazilian athletes (ages 16–21) how to secure
employment by equipping them with the tools and knowledge needed to navigate the job market by
developing the skills and confidence to acquire an internship or part-time job.I observed that for many of the young athletes involved, individuals who had spent years dedicated to
training and competition, often with little preparation for life beyond sports, this experience was
especially transformative. The event helped bridge the gap between athletic and professional careers
by demonstrating how the discipline, resilience, teamwork, and goal-setting developed through sports
are highly transferable to the workforce. Participants learned how to articulate these strengths as
valuable assets, enhancing their confidence in job interviews, workplace settings, and academic
environments.
As they begin to access more stable income sources and long-term opportunities, these
individuals are also better able to support their families and contribute to their communities, helping
to break long-standing cycles of economic vulnerability.

Title: Empowering Kenyan Women Entrepreneurs for Global Impact
Quote:
Our project addressed youth women’s economic exclusion in Nairobi by combining enterprise training, financial inclusion, and mental well‐being support for young women aiming to become entrepreneurs. We worked alongside local partners and supporters to strengthen business skills and community engagement. Our approach was immersive and innovative; therefore, we blended hands‐on workshops, bank‐led financial literacy + know your customer support, market‐readiness activities, and a mental health/self‐esteem module.  A recurring tension surfaced between formal banking requirements and familiar cash/mobile‐money routines. We addressed this by co‐teaching with bank staff, translating fee schedules into plain language, offering low‐fee product options, and running on‐site verification to remove friction. We also encountered gendered expectations voiced by some male instructors, reflecting broader social norms around women’s “appropriate” roles in the household and marketplace. In informal conversations, we heard doubts about “investing in women who will soon marry” and concerns that
confident, economically active women might intimidate men. Such views can dampen aspirations and subtly gatekeep access to opportunity. We addressed this through dialogue-based facilitation, ground rules that center respect and voice, and myth-versus-fact exercises on gender and enterprise. We also used Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s TED Talk “We Should All Be Feminists” as an anchor for small-group reflection on equity, shared prosperity, and why feminism affirms equal dignity and choice, not opposition to men. While shifts were gradual, we observed more supportive classroom behaviors and stronger peer advocacy by the end of the program.
We were challenged to listen first and adapt fast, accepting that success can look different than on paper. The most inspiring moments were the business plan presentations and pitches, as well as the graduation day, when voices that began quietly closed with conviction. We leave with deeper respect for co‐design with local institutions and for the power of
transparent, user‐centered financial inclusion.

Title: Empowering Langa’s Youth: Advancing Sexual Health Education and Community Resources
Quote:
Working alongside the community health
workers (CHWs), we saw how peace emerges from compassion, solidarity, and collective action. that The
teamwork of the CHWS, their intrinsic passion for serving their community, and their unwavering
commitment showed us that peace is built through an appreciation of our shared humanity and that
meaningful progress happens when we work together
.
Our project has contributed to peace by strengthening the capacity of Kheth’Impilo in Langa and through
promoting sexual health education. In the short-term, there is increased access to sexual health
resources and services for youth in Langa, such as pregnancy testing and access to contraception at the
KI Wellness Hub. Our project also placed a heavy emphasis on education and awareness around all
topics related to sexual health including STIs, sexual hygiene, reproductive anatomy, contraception, and
consent. In the long-term, we hope this project helps shift the cultural narrative around sexual health, and
promotes more dialogue to ensure youth are educated and able to make informed decisions. We

Title: Empowering Timorese Youth through Enhanced Education: Building a Future of Change and Progress
Quote:
Our project was designed with a clear focus on peacebuilding, grounded in the belief that enhanced education is essential for empowering youth to become effective leaders and active volunteers. The program emphasized two complementary pillars: leadership and volunteerism, both of which serve as pathways to fostering a peaceful and inclusive society.

The initiative brought together 40 secondary school students from eight high schools across six municipalities of Timor-Leste. The participants engaged for one week in workshops, discussions, and interactive activities designed to equip them with knowledge and practical skills to address challenges such as gender equality, civic engagement, mental health awareness, social inclusion, and education access. These topics were carefully chosen to be relevant and current, ensuring participants understood the realities of their communities and were prepared to lead before engaging in volunteerism or community-based initiatives.

Leadership was emphasized as a core pathway to peace. Participants learned to communicate effectively, think critically, and collaborate across differences. Sessions on public speaking, conflict resolution, and civic engagement provided practical tools for students to act as responsible leaders within their schools and communities. By combining theoretical knowledge with interactive exercises, students gained confidence and a clearer understanding of how leadership can promote harmony, inclusivity, and problem-solving at both local and municipal levels.

Volunteerism was introduced as the practical application of leadership. Activities and discussions highlighted the importance of service to others and the impact of youth-led initiatives in fostering community cohesion. Participants explored how acts of service, ranging from environmental clean-ups to awareness campaigns, can build unity, empathy, and a culture of peace. Through these experiences, students realized that volunteering is not only a responsibility but also a powerful tool for creating positive change.

A central component of the camp was enabling participants to design their own project initiatives for implementation in their schools and communities. Working in small groups, students identified challenges relevant to their local context and created action plans to address them.

Title: Empowering Young Peruvian Women Through Financial Literacy Workshops: A Path to Peace and Prosperity
Quote:
My vision of peace is a world where people from diverse backgrounds come together to create solutions
that promote justice and prosperity. In my view, peace is not merely the absence of conflict, it’s the
presence of opportunity. It’s the moment a young woman realizes she has the right and the ability to
make decisions about her life, future, and finances. Furthermore, peace is built when knowledge replaces
fear, and when access to tangible tools allows one to imagine a future rooted and solidified in dignity and
autonomy. The decision to focus on financial education came from conversations with friends, family members,
community peers, and youth in Concepción who shared and voiced concerns about not knowing how to
manage money, save, or plan for their future. Additionally, the lack of understanding of the official banking
system and its bureaucratic process has led many neighbors to turn to financial entities with less
bureaucracy but greater monetary risk. This has been the reality for many
women who, in search of a decent income, have fallen into scams and debts at an early age. In this
context and understanding the growing and latent challenges affecting my community, the idea of crafting
a contextualized financial education project for female high school students was born. The aim was to
provide practical, dynamic, and decentralized financial education including tools and resources that will
protect future generations from economic and social vulnerability. The project had two key components: a
theoretical one and a practical one. After recognizing that financial literacy is a powerful tool for
autonomy, we incorporated group dynamics, intergenerational mentorship, and visual materials to ensure
the learning experience was both accessible and meaningful.

Title: EmpowHER: Financial Education for a Safer Future
Quote:
I chose to address the issue of financial illiteracy in Romania because of my personal background
and direct experience with its consequences. Growing up in post-communist Romania, I witnessed how
the lack of financial education disproportionately affected rural communities and women, fostering cycles
of dependency, abuse, and vulnerability. I decided to focus on financial education as a peace-building tool
because I believe it empowers individuals with the knowledge to achieve independence, reduce
vulnerability to exploitation, and challenge systemic inequalities. My strategy was to partner with
FeminEast, an emerging NGO already trusted by local communities, to create a free online curriculum
and deliver in-person workshops to students between 14 and 35 years old. By targeting students, we are
able to instill the basics of financial education from an early age, equipping them with the tools to make
informed decisions, avoid cycles of dependency, and build a foundation for long-term independence and
community resilience. This blended approach allowed us to combine broad digital access with personal
community engagement. Our methodology was centered on participant feedback and culturally relevant
resources, ensuring the project directly met the needs of young women and minorities.  This project has reinforced my belief that education is one of the most powerful tools for social
change and community building. It challenged me to think about peace not in abstract terms, but in
practical, everyday actions like teaching someone how to manage their finances and have an emergency
savings account, which can ripple into greater autonomy, reduced violence, and stronger communities. It
inspired me to view leadership as a collaborative effort, where listening to local voices and building trust
are just as important as designing a curriculum. With the support of volunteers, experts, and students, we
were able to take the first step toward financial empowerment.
