Title: Fostering Community in Hokkaido: Encouraging Reconciliation and Cross-cultural Communication Through Visual Novels.
Fostering Interest in STEM Careers Through Access and Exposure
Quote:
Without equal access to educational resources and support, there can be no peace. I believe
peace means creating opportunities for underserved students to flourish, learn, and grow.Rekora addressed the limited exposure to STEM resources that high school students in
underserved communities in Lagos, Nigeria, face. This issue often causes them to lose interest in
STEM subjects and career paths, even before they can try them out. Through school outreaches and
a full-day bootcamp, we introduced students to a variety of hands-on neuroscience experiments,
numerous STEM resources, and valuable career support to enable them to develop or nurture their
interests in STEM fields. Rekora has broadened my understanding of access creation and inspired me to keep building
systems that enable students to thrive, regardless of their background. However, it also reminded me
that there is a lot of work to be done. The 360+ students we engaged with are a fraction of the
hundreds of thousands of high school students in Lagos, and millions across Nigeria, who have
inadequate STEM resources. My experience this summer has opened a new pathway for me to
contribute to the educational system at home, and encouraged me to keep supporting the next
generation of students.

Title: Fostering Peace through Education, Intercultural Exchange, and Sustainable Development in Tanzania
Quote:
Our Project For Peace aimed at strengthening the relationship between Germany and Tanzania through
Intercultural Exchange, Education and Sustainability. For that, we worked with the German association
GoForTansania which connected us to the Brilliant Pre-Primary and Primary school in Ushirika,
Tanzania. The Tanzanian school is fully funded by GoForTansania in cooperation with the German High
School Gymnasium Mainz Oberstadt (GMO).
 For the first branch, we organized school lessons that provided political,
historic and sustainable information for German students at GMO. For that, we recruited experts from
these fields to provide professional insights into topics like the German-Tanzanian Political Relations,
the History of German Colonialism in Tanzania, and Contemporary Sustainability Issues in Tanzania.
The evaluation of the school lessons revealed great interest from German students in personal
contributions to strengthen the relationship between both countries and to get engaged in the
community to help make the lives of the students in Ushirika easier. Additionally, the exchange between
both schools was fostered by pictures, representing Tanzania, that were drawn by the Tanzanian
students and sent to Germany. To promote the association's visibility, we contributed to its marketing
by using the self-made pictures from Tanzania and created stickers with the association's brand logo.
To help raise funds for the association we funded cans which are spread all over the German school
property and will be used for students to throw out their plastic bottles. Germanys recycle system gives
25 cents for each recycled plastic bottle. This money will be used to continue sustainable funding of the
Tanzanian school. The second branch was addressed by organizing material for the Tanzanian students. One of the achievements was the organization and funding of sewing machines which the
students will learn to use at school. Moreover, we wanted to put emphasis on the needs of the school
in Tanzania. Therefore, we contributed to infrastructural advancements within the housing situation of
the students and future volunteers. Beds as well as mattresses were organized. Moreover, a guestroom
for volunteers was created. For the last branch, Sustainability, we managed to organize solar panels for
the school in Tanzania. This will allow the school to produce their own electricity, which will lower costs
for electricity in the long run.

Title: From Desperation to Dignity: Empowering Children with Clean and Hygienic Spaces
Quote:
For me, peace is not only the absence of conflict but the presence of dignity, safety, and access to
necessities. With my project I was able to provide the students of Basanta Primary School’s with hygienic
washrooms and clean water, which would result in a safer learning environment for them. This small step
is important to restore dignity and create opportunities for growth as most of the students belong to a
marginalized community. In the short term, the facilities are expected to improve attendance, reduce the
bad odors around the school, build dignity among the students and raise awareness of hygiene. In the long
term, the project would support the commitment towards SDG 6 for Nepal, protect the environment and
provide basic sanitation facilities to generations of students to study at the Basanta Primary School. “If we look around the world, there are countless opportunities to make a difference in people’s lives, but it
is also a fact that everyone’s problem cannot be solved. Too often, we forget how privileged we are,
because the things we consider ‘normal’ such as clean water, a safe bathroom and dignity are luxuries for
many. Across the globe, there are people who wake up every day wishing for the simple comforts we take
for granted. The Peace Grant allowed me to build a washroom that is far more than just a physical structure
and is a testament of dignity, a step towards equality, and a symbol of peace that will serve generations of
students at Basanta Primary School.”
— Ronish Acharya, The College of Idaho

Title: From Margins to Center:  Education as a Tool for Roma Youth Empowerment
Quote:
“From Margins to Center” promotes education as a powerful tool in combating systemic discrimination
against Roma youth in Skopje. Along with SUMNAL NGO, our team ensures that Roma children and
teenagers get academic support and encouragement, while also engaging in enjoyable summer activities
that promote inclusion, cultural immersion and respect as members of the broader Macedonian society. In terms of the strategies we implemented hand-in-hand with the NGO, our project mainly fostered
connections between Roma youth, educators, and the broader community by creating spaces for
dialogue, collaboration and enjoyment. Our weekly community meetings and feedback sessions
encouraged Roma children to actively engage in their education and share their ideas, challenges,
desires and spaces for improvement. We also collected and showcased their educational and creative
achievements and crafts. Our anticipated short-term outcome increased educational engagement among
the Roma community, with the long-term goal of creating a more inclusive and equitable community for
the Roma youth to grow and thrive in.
Overall our project involved ~45 children, including younger primary school children, who
benefited from tutoring sessions (especially sessions they didn’t have before such as computing lessons)
and various cultural trips. Our weekly schedule included a mix of foundational skill-building activities,
academic sessions, creative workshops integrating arts and science, and excursions to cultural and
educational sites like local museums, libraries and nature destinations. In this project, education served as a foundation for empowerment and breaking
cycles of poverty and barriers that persist for Roma communities in North Macedonia. We achieved short
term goals such as actively funding SUMNAL kids education and teaching them about how education
changed our lives. In the long term, we aim for people across the world to learn about SUMNAL through
the meaningful work we have done with them in the span of a month. But something they do every day.
This is what peace means to us: an initiative that is sustainable because of those who care and will care.

Title: From Silence to Story
Quote:
Personally, for me, peace is the freedom to express yourself, to break through the silence, and to be able to tell your story and be heard by the world.  As a man who managed to come to the U.S., I deeply felt for the girls left behind in Afghanistan and wanted to do something tangible to support them. Having worked in education and being a strong believer in the right to education regardless of gender, I designed the project to combine leadership and advocacy training with hands-on podcast creation, providing participants with the tools, confidence, and platform to reclaim their voices, share their stories, and advocate for education, empowerment, and peace. This project has changed how I used to see education and working with Afghan girls who faced extreme barriers showed me their resilience, curiosity, and hunger for learning. Many were amazed by technology and podcasting, eager to learn despite challenging timing and internet obstacles. Hearing their podcast stories was incredibly inspiring and their courage, creativity, and determination reinforced the power of storytelling and education to drive change and promote peace. This project not only amplified the voices of Afghan girls but also inspired me to deepen my work through my own nonprofit, continuing to contribute to education, empowerment, and the future of Afghan society.
“Silencing women will never lead to a prosperous and brighter Afghanistan; true progress lies in empowering them.”

Title: FutureReady
Quote: The Future Ready project addressed the lack of career guidance among secondary school students in Chókwè, Mozambique—a gap that often leads to low motivation, disengagement from studies, and ultimately high dropout rates. Without clear direction, many young people face early marriage or pregnancy, or are forced to seek low-paying jobs under difficult conditions in neighboring countries. By partnering with local organizations, hosting workshops, and sharing resources, this initiative provided students with career counseling and entrepreneurship opportunities. During one of the workshops on dreams, the coach asked the students what they thought my dream was. A student answered: “Mana (big sister) Lau’s dream is that our dreams come true.” That moment felt like the climax of the project, when both the students and I realized that our dreams are connected in ways bigger than ourselves. Their response captured the true goal of the project—not just career guidance, but being part of a larger cycle where what they dream and accomplish can spark change for future generations.

Title: Gardens of Peace
Quote:
For our team, peace is about creating conditions where people can thrive, making sure basic needs are
met, reducing unnecessary burdens, and building systems that promote dignity and resilience. Our project
may have been small, but it was a step in that direction. By tackling something as practical as irrigation,
we aimed to make farming at Willow Run Acres more sustainable and to free up time and energy for
education and community connection.

Title: GeoPasture
Quote:
The project addresses climate-induced, resource-driven conflicts affecting pastoralist communities in
Northern Laikipia, Kenya, by equipping Maasai herders with mobile solar power and a community-led digital
toolset for real-time livestock tracking, geofencing, and climate-aware grazing decisions, paired with training
and dialogue. We worked with IMPACT Kenya, leaders and members of Maiyanat Community Land, to install
the app, run FPIC-based workshops, and co-create a local monitoring group to facilitate feedback and
provide technical support. We focused on reducing
resource competition and associated violence by improving pastoralists’ access to actionable information
(pasture availability, movement patterns) and by creating a practical, shared process for dialogue and
decision-making.
The strategy combined: (1) a mobile app and GPS collars for geofencing/traceability; (2) hands-on digital
literacy sessions and dialogue; and (3) a community-run channel (WhatsApp + committee oversight) for peer
support and rapid feedback.  Peace is the capacity of communities to manage scarce resources fairly and access information easily, with
trusted channels for dialogue and problemsolving, so that disputes de-escalate into mediation and
cooperation instead of violence.

In the short-term, there was a high local uptake of the app, formal FPIC approval, successful installation on
all participating phones, hands-on training, and the creation of a community monitoring channel. Herders
immediately used geofencing and real-time views to plan grazing and to track high-value animals (e.g.,
camels and cows), increasing a sense of security and clear access to information. Long term, geofencing
and animal live-tracking data can reduce accidental encroachment, deter theft, and lower the frequency of
climate-induced resource-related confrontations. The Peace Hub will serve as a place of convening, training,
peer learning and co-managing tools.  The project made me understand that no matter how good an idea is, it will only create positive impact when
it receives community uptake.  Working towards peace and justice is to talk with the community, not for them.

Title: Ghana 3D: Bridging Tradition and Innovation in Assistive Devices
Quote:
To me, peace begins with empowerment through knowledge. In contexts where access to education and
technology is unequal, peace requires bridging divides and providing opportunities that can transform
both individual futures and community health outcomes. This project introduced digital fabrication methods for prosthetics and orthotics (assistive devices) to
clinicians and students in Ghana, combining theoretical and practical training. Through 30 online and in-
person sessions, participants were educated about 3D scanning, digital design, and 3D printing as
modern alternatives to traditional plaster-based workflows. A key challenge was adapting to the evolving political situation and travel restrictions. While initially
disappointing, it ultimately created a model for delivering high-quality remote workshops. I encountered
moments of frustration—such as unstable connectivity or varying attendance—but these were
opportunities to innovate with flexible scheduling, recorded materials, and ongoing support through
WhatsApp. Of the 90 participants, 72
responded: 87% rated the workshops “very helpful”. Comments highlighted that the training not only
improved their technical knowledge and potential to improve the standards of assistive devices in Ghana,
but also strengthened their confidence to pursue advanced studies in Europe, the UK, and the US.

Title: Grandma's Kitchen
Quote:
Grandma's Kitchen in Parana, Brazil in a partnership with the CRAS community center worked to combat
isolation among elderly women. The project improved their physical, and mental well-being by offering a
space to cook together while fostering social reintegration and nutrition. While the project had a clear impact on the participants, it was even more interesting to see how it influenced others beyond the immediate group. For example, the local economy benefited
through partnerships with nearby businesses, a university expressed interest in helping expand the
project, and many students were inspired by the talks I gave about peace and becoming agents of
change. On a personal level, my own grandmother was affected as well, as she spent more time with me
and contributed ideas and recipes to the project.Peace is finding constants in the midst of chaos. One of the biggest lessons I learned from this project is that even if I can’t change someone’s entire life, I can still make part of it better.I was surprised how much I learned by listening and observing. The most effective social initiatives are often those small actions that often go by unnoticed.

Title: Growing Peace: School Gardens for Learning, Climate and Nutrition in Kenya
Quote:
The Growing Peace Project addressed student malnutrition and limited practical education resources at
Mugumo-ini Primary School in Kiambu County, Kenya, through the construction of a comprehensive
school garden system featuring eight raised beds, complete irrigation infrastructure, and curriculum
integration. Working directly with 1,500 students, teachers, and community members, the project
employed a participatory design-build methodology that engaged learners in every phase of
development from site preparation through final planting and maintenance protocols. A significant conflict we encountered involved balancing project timeline pressures with meaningful
student participation when external disruptions compressed our available working time. Rather than
excluding students to maintain efficiency, we chose to involve them in problem-solving discussions
about adapting to changed circumstances, which ultimately strengthened their ownership of the project
while teaching valuable lessons about resilience and flexibility. This experience highlighted the
importance of viewing obstacles as opportunities for deeper learning rather than impediments to
predetermined outcomes.This project fundamentally changed how we understand the relationship between education, nutrition,
and community development. We learned that schools can serve as powerful catalysts for broader
social transformation when they embrace participatory approaches that honor both local knowledge and
innovative solutions. The experience reinforced our belief that sustainable development must be driven
by communities themselves rather than imposed from outside, and that young people are capable of
remarkable leadership when given genuine responsibility and support.

Title: Gyanko Pul, Computer Literacy Project for Nepali Students
Quote:
Gyanko Pul, Computer Literacy Project for Nepali Students, addressed education inequality in rural
communities in Nepal by expanding student access to school computers and implementing a three
week-long foundational computer skills training for 120 students in grades 8, 9, and 10 at Kusumakar
Secondary School. The project’s goal was to provide young children from lower-economic backgrounds
with the foundational computer skills needed to participate in the global economy, access world
information, and explore national and international career opportunities.  Throughout the project, there was wholehearted support from the school and the
communities, including the principal, teachers, ward chair of the local community, parents, and students.
The school provided a classroom for conducting the computer class for students, and the school
authorities and local government contributed to evaluating and buying computers, and other necessary
support throughout the program. In addition, the school computer teacher and participating students
helped to set up and organize the computer lab.conflict. Peace is a safe space where people can learn, share ideas,
and respect each other's values. Therefore, we believe education is one of the best ways to achieve such
peace. Our project focused on education, providing students basic computer skills and helping them to
build confidence in these skills. We created a space for students from different backgrounds to interact
with each other and cultivate understanding. In the short term, the project benefited students by granting
them access to computers and foundational computer knowledge and skills. In the long term, the project
will promote inclusivity in computer education while opening doors for higher education nationwide and
abroad.

Title: Harmony in Schools: Advocacy for Students and Teachers
Quote:
This project supported social-emotional learning by providing elementary school students in two Metro
Nashville Public Schools with well-being and calming tools and practices. Additionally, the project created
stress reduction strategies and resources for teachers and staff in those schools to promote a more
supportive classroom environment. This project supported social-emotional learning by providing elementary school students in two Metro
Nashville Public Schools with well-being and calming tools and practices. Additionally, the project created
stress reduction strategies and resources for teachers and staff in those schools to promote a more
supportive classroom environment.  This project will focus on supporting the new Advocacy Center initiative in MNPS, which emphasizes trauma-informed practices
and alternative disciplinary measures. The project seeks to reduce suspensions and foster a supportive
school environment by equipping schools with resources and training to support students in conflict
resolution, emotional regulation, and restorative practices.
I worked with the
guidance counselors, advocacy coaches, and principals to fulfill the needs and support for the schools. I
was able to support the calm corners in each classroom by adding de-escalation and emotional regulation
tools. In doing so, the classrooms’ calm corners are more uniform making it easier for students to
recognize the tools as they continue throughout elementary school. For teacher well-being I was able to
transform the teacher lounges into calming and welcoming spaces. This included soft lighting, stress
reliever tools, and special requests made by teachers at each school. This project has taught me the importance of creating compassionate learning environments for all by
advocating for both students and teachers. The project has inspired me to continue advocating for compassionate learning environments for all. I am
now considering entering the field of advocacy law after college because of my experiences this summer.

Title: Healing Minds
Quote:
The Healing Minds project addressed the lack of mental health support for Sudanese women refugees
aged 18–30 in Cairo, who often experience trauma without access to specialized care. Working with
Sudanese women, the project provided culturally sensitive workshops and counseling sessions led by
trusted professionals, emphasizing trauma-informed care, emotional regulation, and coping strategies
while building a supportive community.  This project contributed to peace by helping women rebuild their sense of self and resilience in
the short term, while also planting seeds of long-term empowerment through coping strategies and peer
networks.
One conflict I encountered was skepticism and resistance within the community itself, as mental health
support was unfamiliar and even stigmatized. Navigating this required patience, evidence, and consistent
transparency. I would like to learn more about community-based trust-building and culturally tailored
approaches to reduce stigma around mental health care.
The project changed the way I see the world by reminding me that peace and healing often begin in
small, personal spaces—through conversations, shared stories, and mutual support.

Title: Healthy Futures for Peace in Makola and Kejetia Markets
Quote:
The Healthy Futures for Peace project addressed the growing burden of lifestyle and preventable
diseases among Ghanaian market women through a combination of health education, free screenings,
and local partnerships. Implemented in Makola Market (Accra) and Kejetia Market (Kumasi), the initiative
partnered with the Muslim Health Students’ Association of Ghana (MUHSAG), the Muslim Health
Workers’ Association of Ghana (MHWAG), and the Ako Health Foundation. Together, we sought to
empower women with knowledge and access to preventive care, recognizing that their well-being directly
sustains families and promotes stability in the community. To me, peace is more than the absence of conflict; it is the presence of health, security, and dignity. This
project contributes to peace by reducing the destabilizing effects of preventable disease. When market
women are healthy, they can continue providing for their children, keeping them in school and preventing
the economic hardship that often leads to instability. In the short term, peace was visible in the relief of
women who understood their health risks for the first time. In the long term, peace will be visible in
stronger families and more resilient communities. Not everything was easy. One challenge we
encountered was skepticism from some market women, who initially feared that screenings might lead to
hidden costs or stigmatization. We navigated this by working closely with respected community leaders
and market queens, who publicly endorsed the project and reassured women of its benefits. This
experience taught me that building trust is as important as providing services, and that effective
community health work must be rooted in cultural respect and relationships.

Title: Her Crimson Fight: Awakening Justice For Every Voice
HIV Awareness and Stigma Reduction in Rwanda
Quote:
Our project addressed the issue of HIV stigma among youth in Rwanda, which often prevents students
from seeking testing, care, and open conversation. We created and implemented Guhuza, an
UNO-inspired HIV awareness card game, alongside peer discussions and student-led facilitation, reaching ~300 university students and ~30 high school students in Kigali and Rwamagana through multiple local
partnerships. Student facilitators are now equipped to run future sessions with the provided decks, facilitator
guide, and SOPs. Based on feedback, we plan to develop a Kinyarwanda edition, create tiered
difficulty decks, and expand the model to cover life skills and mental health topics. Peace means enabling dignity and inclusion—creating environments where stigma is dismantled and
individuals can speak openly without fear. In the short term, participants practiced naming HIV confidently and challenging misconceptions in respectful peer discussions. In the long term, normalizing conversation among youth helps reduce stigma, encouraging care-seeking and supporting healthier communities. We learned that sustainable peacebuilding looks less like one-off campaigns and more like small, replicable mechanisms embedded in communities. Seeing student leaders execute with
professionalism reminded us of the untapped capacity within youth networks, and confirmed that
empowering them is key to long-term change. Personal Statements

Title: Increasing Access to Water Aimed at Reducing Intercommunal Conflicts Among Pastoralist Communities in Tonj North County, Warrap State-South Sudan
Inland Empire Voices Heard
Quote:
This summer’s project highlights the diversity, beauty, and resiliency of immigrant, LGBTQ+, BIPOC, and other historically marginalized communities in the Inland Empire in the face of political and socio- economic challenges. Through a Spanish English book, Una Voz de Esperanza: 20 Stories From The Inland Empire, this project documented local community members and organizers associated with Inland Coalition for Immigrant Justice (IC4IJ), in their pursuit to thrive and work within their neighborhoods in the Inland Empire. At the book celebration held in September, I
witnessed how this project contributed to peace in how confident and self-assured participants were. I
saw their family members and friends look at them with such pride and recognition, that these community
members are seen, heard, and their words eternalized. A conflict I endured during this project included
using photographs that make people feel safe and secure during this time of fear and facial recognition
used against immigrant bodies. Thus, while there were many times, I captured beautiful portraits, I also had to prepare photos that provided more obscurity to their identity in respect to their privacy and safety.
Thus, the most ‘aesthetic’ photo-choice I learned in this project is one that empowers and provides
comfort to the participants. In conducting this project, I found that I have not felt more pride and joy than
when celebrating people’s stories and meeting with people. I hope to continue this work of storytelling
within immigrant communities and highlighting the joy and resiliency at the heart of them.

Title: Innovation for Peace: Innovative Idea Competition in Public Universities
Quote:
Youth must be active participants and leaders in sustaining peace. And the path to meaningful youth
engagement in the peace process requires a different strategy, creative approach, and deliberate lens. As
forces for good across a range of social domains, entrepreneurship/innovation is a flexible space to engage
young people, inspire creativity, and promote peace.
The Innovation for Peace (I4P) Ethiopia project aimed to promote sustainable peace through the lenses of
innovation and creation of inclusive platforms in prominent public universities in conflict affected setting.
Ultimately, the project aspired to contribute to create local economic opportunities for young
undergraduates, reduce violence, and contribute to long term stability and harmony through young peace
promoters.
Towards this end, the inclusive youth platforms played a vital role to empower aspiring youth entrepreneurs
in social innovation, enhance conflict awareness and youth voice, and develop creative peace building
solutions in the community. Using young people’s passion for innovation and economic independence, the
I4P has created platforms in targeted public universities for youth driven peace contributions through
catalyzing innovation and created favorable spaces for elevating spirit self-employment as a viable career
path thereby contributing to economic diversification and social innovation. It fostered a sense of purpose
among participated student communities and promoted culture of entrepreneurship thereby creating local
solutions for community problems. More importantly, the I4P has facilitated finalists to be a new generation
of youth peace actors who incorporated peace promotion concepts in their business ideas/planning and
idea pitches. In addition, the I4P has laid a solid foundation and strategies to grow, and lessons that would
serve as diagnostic evidence to leverage the key toolkit in public universities.

Title: Inspirational Indonesian Women
Quote:
This project collaborated with local communities to foster conversations, host workshops, and
create a children’s book celebrating the lives of inspirational Indonesian women, each featured with a
biography and portrait. Co-created with schoolteachers and children aged 7–12, the book included
interactive workbook-style pages to encourage personal reflection and empowerment, inspiring the next
generation of Indonesian children to stand for gender equality, girls’ rights, and peace.  The book wasn’t just written for Indonesian girls–it was written with them. From initial feedback via Zoom and WhatsApp, to joyful brainstorming in the
Jakarta workshops, these community members helped shape every page. Local teachers suggested
historical figures we had overlooked. Children shared stories about their mothers and sisters. Their input
was invaluable, from ensuring a wide variety of careers to determining which achievements and passions
to highlight. Together, we built something rooted in our very own hopes and dreams.
The initial idea was to develop the book entirely in person. But logistical hurdles, particularly with
the timing issue of printing the book, led us to pivot: we began remotely, then convened in Jakarta for an
intensive month-long workshop. That shift unexpectedly broadened participation: it would have been
more difficult to get everyone at the same location, especially considering how large the Greater Jakarta
area is. Because we communicated mostly on Whatsapp, it was actually quite easy to get a variety of
voices, regardless of geographical restrictions. Of course, the remote model came with some setbacks -
there were many tech hiccups, and I felt I couldn’t glean as much richness from the discussions as I could
in real life. But the diversity of perspectives was worth it, and is something I couldn’t get from the real-life
sessions. “I hope this project will have ignited the passion for justice and equality in the hearts of young
readers. Through these conversations and the book, I believe this project has facilitated community
cohesion and liberating conversations, all in the pursuit of peace. This is the true fight for women: a story
unearthed, an intellectual reckoning, the subsumption of courage.”

Title: Irrigation System in An Internally Displaced Cooperative’s Farm
Quote:
The project implemented an irrigation system on the farm of Association AGNAWÊ GOMI, a cooperative
of displaced Burkinabe women in Ouangolodougou engaged in small-scale farming.  After identifying the main
needs of Association AGNAWÊ GOMI which are coping with irregular rainfall and learning new farming
techniques, it was clear that building an irrigation system would make the biggest impact. This would
allow them to produce crops year-round without fear of the dry season, diversify their agricultural
production, increase their income, and at the same time receive training in sustainable farming practices.This project contributed to empowering women in a male-centered activity. It gave them a sense of
courage, belonging, and support while bridging the gap of gender inequality and exclusion. At the same
time, it helped restore some of the societal damage caused by the ongoing security crisis in Burkina
Faso. By offering training on irrigation system maintenance and sustainable farming practices, the women
gained the authority to independently manage the infrastructure. This knowledge boosted both their
productivity and annual revenue. In many ways, our project contributed to peace by restoring dignity,
enabling financial independence, and improving the well-being of their children and, in turn, their
communities as future changemakers.

Title: Kel Chai Ich Project: Higher Education Access
Quote:
Peace involves creating environments where individuals can pursue their aspirations freely, without
fear of judgment or limitation. By enabling young women to access education, Kel Chai Ich contributes
to peace in both the short and long term. In the immediate sense, it provides girls with the tools to
achieve their goals. Over time, it fosters a more equitable and inclusive society by challenging norms
and creating opportunities for future generations.
While the Kel Chai Ich project supported higher education aspirations, it also built understanding
between parents and students. In Kyrgyzstan, family decision-making is central, so we embraced this
by providing shared language and information for families to discuss opportunities together. We
worked directly with parents, inviting them to workshops where we shared opportunities for their
daughters and encouraged them to become advocates. Parents inspired by our discussions
volunteered to chaperone a three-day field trip, building trust and collaboration. This year, 15 parents
attended our gathering, bringing thoughtful questions and voicing concerns about working with a local
organization like ours. Some were initially skeptical about the program and funding, but I addressed
this through open conversations, sharing my background and the purpose of the grant, while
maintaining clear boundaries with students.

Title: Knowledge for Peace: Egiye Jao, A Parent Education Initiative in Rangamati
Quote:
This project affirmed my commitment to building peace through inclusion and education. One woman
shared how Egiye Jao reignited her passion for learning after she had been denied an education as a
child while her brothers continued in school. For years she felt invisible, yet through the program she felt
‘seen’ for the first time and was able to showcase her intelligence and curiosity. Her story showed me that
peace emerges when communities practice inclusion and respect, transforming everyday interactions into
acts of reconciliation. When individuals are given opportunities to learn, to be valued, and to have their
voices heard, they are able to flourish, and that flourishing strengthens the bonds of peace within their
communities. Her story reminded me that peace is built from the ground up, through everyday acts of
inclusion and the creation of spaces where people can thrive.

Title: Leer Mexico Read -- An Oasis of Peace
Quote:
I collaborated with John Omernik and Sergio Balgañón of Leer Mexico Read in Itzapalapa, Mexico City to produce a documentary titled Oasis. The resulting film highlights how the education center serves as an oasis for peace by fostering empathy, personal growth, and nonviolent conflict resolution.
produced a documentary titled Oasis. 
Interviews were conducted with members of the community served by Leer Mexico Read in Iztapalapa. Questions included: “What does peace mean to you?”; “What role has Leer Mexico Read played in your personal journey toward peace?”; and “What is your message of peace to the world?” A 35-minute documentary was produced with Spanish and English audio and English subtitles, exploring the role of education in promoting understanding, empathy, and personal growth, as well as the choice of peaceful over violent means of conflict resolution. Additional short videos were created to share with prospective teachers, donors, and community members interested in learning more about Leer Mexico Read. Remaining funds were donated to support the site’s supplies and routine operations. 
The documentary addressed how educational centers can be means of promoting personal growth, the formation of healthy habits, empathy, nonviolent conflict resolution, and community-level peace at large.

Title: Luz da Esperança - Peacebuilding Through Fighting Energy Poverty
Quote:
Luz da Esperança was a peace-building project that aimed to reduce energy poverty,
deforestation, and pain caused by smoke in a neglected community in Kachene, Mozambique. I worked
with Mysol Moçambique to provide 66 solar panel kits to the community and 3 to the local primary school.

It is estimated that about 300 people were positively impacted by the project. They no longer need to start their day earlier because access to electricity has empowered them to continue their activities even after sunset. Families who asked to have a of solar-powered LED light in the outside area of their houses will be better able to protect themselves
from creeping venomous animals such as scorpions and snakes.The light makes it so that people can feel safer in the night. Access to a clean source of energy will also allow people to access a better
quality of air. There will be less exposure to respiratory diseases and to spreading fires caused by
candles or lamps, especially for elderly people with vulnerable lungs or families. Classes can still be held effectively at the local primary school, even on low-light days or during winter, when it gets dark earlier than in summer. Children can now work on their homework and study at night at home. The teachers can also work on their grades and prepare classes at night in their homes.
The families are now accessing a free source of energy that
would take them years to purchase by themselves, given that most of the families rely on subsistence
agriculture and do not have the financial means to afford solar panel kits. Now that the families and
teachers can use solar power to replace their kerosene lamps and battery-powered candles, they do not
need to continue buying these temporary light sources. This allows them to save and invest their money
into other basic needs, such as food, education, their families, or improving things in their houses. Luz da
Esperança has also contributed to helping reduce the community's dependency on firewood for lighting,
which is believed will reduce deforestation and avoid potential future conflicts led by vegetation damage
over the next years. Lastly, the young people who took part in the training to help maintain the kits have
also gained a new role in their community, and with it, they have gained an additional way to support
themselves and their community. I feel that this project experience opened my eyes to a big issue that
will still require many more years of work to be solved in my country. After working on this project and
having the chance to learn more about the issues around energy poverty and how it negatively impacts
so many lives, I feel that I finally have the answer to how I can help my people. I found my purpose.

Title: Mentorship Program for Community Peace
Quote:
The Hazleton Horizons Mentorship Program, created in partnership with the Hazleton
Integration Project (HIP), is a year-round initiative designed to guide first-generation Hispanic middle
school students in Hazleton, Pennsylvania, through critical stages of academic and personal
development. By pairing students with culturally reflective mentors and hosting consistent weekly
engagement, including ten summer events serving 25–35 students and featuring three college field trips,
the program offers career and college exploration, social-emotional skill building, and measurable growth
in career readiness and socio-emotional development.Peace is rooted in relationships. It is not simply the absence of conflict but an active, ongoing
effort to create environments where trust, empathy, and opportunity thrive. Hazleton Horizons embodies
this vision: through mentorship, students found guidance, encouragement, and inspiration in a space
where their experiences were reflected and celebrated.
The program’s measurable successes, demonstrated through pre- and post-program assessments,
captured significant gains in students’ confidence, communication, and career exploration skills. Yet the
true measure of impact came in quieter moments: a student asking their mentor about financial aid,
another proudly sharing their career goals for the first time, or a group of mentees excitedly recounting
their favorite parts of a college campus visit.

Title: Metrology for Peace
Quote:
This project addressed two large issues in Ecuador: insecurity and a lack of job opportunities. This idea
was born out of my own experiences and observations on how these challenges directly affect young
people, especially since I grew up in that area. To make an impact, I implemented a teaching and
certification program in metrology, with the help and partnership of qualified engineers from Ecuador’s only
internationally accredited metrology laboratory, to offer education and prevent young people from joining
criminal organizations due to a lack of job opportunities. This program provided technical training,
employable skills, and hands-on laboratory experience, while also raising awareness of the importance of
metrology in sustainable development. Metrology for Peace defines peace by demonstrating how accurate measurement can be a pillar of equity
and social justice. By training students to apply precise and unbiased measurements in vulnerable sectors
and certifying talent, this program will help reduce conflicts caused by inaccurate measurements and
promote a culture of trust and peace in society. Our working examples included promoting awareness on
the calibration of medical equipment to reduce medical negligence in the human and veterinary health
fields, which fostering peace through practice and ethics, a key message in the course. Since the proper
calibration of equipment ensures safety protocols and reduces economic losses and deaths, it promotes
peace and safety and longevity for our communities. The production of a network for students in the industry
field aims to provide quality-trained professionals focused on metrology activities, offering a network and
community of practice and support, diverting from gang reliance and activities, contributing to a fairer and
more peaceful city. Of our 30 students, 22 students earn their certificate of participation attending all classes and labs. 12 of
those students earned the required 80% on the course to earn international certification. Some of our
students went from not knowing what metrology was, to having an internationally recognized certificate,
and practiced confidence. All partners in the project were pleased with this success.

Title: Midundo Ya Amani ("Rhythms of Peace"): Dance for Sustainable Peace in the Grand Lac Region
Quote:
Physical, emotional, and social safe spaces make change possible. When we feel safe, we can show our
most honest, joyful, creative, and generous selves. Dance helps us create these circles of trust and
belonging. It encourages a deep sense of unity and harmony, both within and between us. This leads us
to say that Midundo Ya Amani wasn’t about teaching dance. It was about using dance to guide young
people to trust themselves and others, to realise the power of the tools within and around them, and to
show up as peacebuilders for their community - to recognise their role as the caretakers of tomorrow,
starting today.
Midundo Ya Amani was a reminder of the power of dance as a catalyst for personal, interpersonal, and
social transformation. As dancers, we speak to humans beyond the social barriers of race, religion,
gender, and language. As artists, we have the power to circulate ideas that challenge the normalised
social orders and power structures. Through this programme, we witnessed how creative expression can
unlock healing, inspire leadership, and offer a path forward in a region that has long suffered from conflict.

Title: Mind Matters: Workshops and Mental Health Resources for Students
Quote:
This project worked on filling a gap in mental health awareness and substance abuse
prevention that is prevalent in Indian communities.The workshop series took place at 16 institutions, with each workshop combining
lectures, discussion, and activities on mental health, resilience, and substance abuse prevention.
Every session was led by at least one psychiatrist, incorporating student feedback to remain
flexible and open to student needs, and aimed to educate participants. I define peace as the process of maintaining the foundations in which communities are
able to thrive, support each other, and sustain development, working towards addressing
differences. I hope that my project will contribute towards peace by providing young Indians
with more awareness of a pressing topic in India. Even if one person, out of the thousands we
saw, was able to seek help and receive the support they needed, then it will have been a job well
done. And in the short term, that is what I hope to see. There are now thousands of students in a
region that know more about mental health, substance abuse prevention, and resources available
to them. I

Title: Missing: Lost Children in the Sulawesi Earthquake and Tsunami (2018)
Motherhood in Safety
Quote:
I define peace as the protection of life and the assurance that every individual can thrive without fear of preventable death. The “Motherhood in Safety” project contributes to peace by safeguarding mothers and
infants, reducing preventable mortality, and fostering community trust in healthcare systems. In the short term, the maternity ward now provides a safe space for women to deliver under professional
care. In the long term, it builds resilience, instills hope, and lays the foundation for improved healthcare infrastructure in Mundri East.
Managing the project remotely was my greatest challenge, particularly in ensuring accountability and meeting deadlines. I overcame this by leveraging the County Health Department’s oversight, maintaining
constant communication with contractors, and engaging local leaders for supervision. This experience strengthened my belief that infrastructure development, when paired with education and empowerment,
can create transformative impact in vulnerable communities.
“Motherhood in Safety affirms my conviction that peace begins with safety; the safety of mothers, infants, and families. Building a maternity ward in my village is more than a construction project; it is a declaration
that every mother’s life is valuable. Despite distance and challenges, determination and community partnership made it possible. For me, peace is giving life a safe beginning."

Title: NABINTU - Peace Through Agriculture
Quote:
Our project, NABINTU, aims to become a platform that serves consumers by providing high-quality,
affordable staple foods; supports retailers with a stable market and reduced risk of bankruptcy; and
partners reliably with farmers to ensure the consistent purchase of their crops. Located in Kashusha, a
farming village in the eastern region of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), we are in close
proximity to some of the country’s most fertile lands—areas with the potential to feed the entire nation.
Unfortunately, this natural gift has been stifled by decades of conflict, forcing the population to rely on
costly imports and contributing to widespread malnutrition and undernutrition. Throughout this project, we have collaborated with over 20 individuals, compensating them for their
valuable services. This summer, we partnered with two additional workers and hired transportation
services to deliver the machines to our facility. All of the people we've worked with so far are talented
young adults who, due to limited job opportunities, had previously been unemployed. Although many of
them worked with us for only a short period, they were deeply grateful to receive payment for the first time
in a while. They expressed how much they enjoyed working with us and shared their hope that we would
begin hiring soon. Many felt proud that, for the first time in years, there may be a Congolese-owned local
company that benefits other Congolese business owners such as farmers, retailers, and transportation
services. The excitement surrounding the NABINTU project has fueled our confidence in its long-term
success. With this
funding, we successfully completed the corn flour processing line, which had been on hold since last
summer. Acquiring equipment was the most challenging aspect of the initiative, and thanks to Projects for Peace, we overcame that barrier and are now preparing for operational testing. Throughout this journey, I honed my leadership and managerial skills by ensuring we made the most of the resources available and achieved critical milestones.
In addition, PfP support allowed us to pay for local services, providing a meaningful financial boost to
small businesses in a region suffering from a rebel-induced economic drought. The individuals who
supported the transport of our machines, the local manufacturer who produced the milling equipment, and the construction team that installed the doors, windows, and concrete pavement were all direct
beneficiaries of the funding. This marks the beginning of a broader economic revitalization that promises
to build a better life for the community.

Title: Nagasaki Echoes Project. Previously called: "Taking a step to achieve peace by preventing the nuclear tragedy"
Quote:
We organized the Nagasaki Echoes Project to deliver the message of the inhumanity of nuclear weapons through the experience of Nagasaki, and it is divided into two main phases; the first phase took place when we held a survivor’s testimony session at our university, where an atomic bomb survivor (or Hibakusha) shared their
experience, a professor at the Research Center for Nuclear Weapons Abolition (RECNA) at Nagasaki University gave a lecture on issues surrounding nuclear weapons, and we hosted the afternoon discussion event about “how to be a responsible global citizen in relation to nuclear abolition." In the second phase, we organized an atomic bomb exhibition at ICU, with photographs about the Nagasaki atomic bombings, testimonies from survivors, and information about nuclear weapons. I define peace as a world where people can connect, cooperate, and strive to make it a better place. If people try to hurt each other, militarize nations, and create separation among people from different nations, that would not be a peaceful world. Nonetheless, a world with nuclear weapons, which are designed to destroy people and the earth, is not needed in the world I define as peace. Our project contributed to peace by delivering the message of “the inhumanity of nuclear weapons
through Nagasaki’s experience,” and that same thing could happen if we do not do anything in the
current situation. To do that, we aimed to connect three dots in all our events: past, present, and future. At the exhibition, we exhibited the devastating experience of Nagasaki, to show “past,” the current world situation with nuclear weapons to show “present,” and created an open area to write about the visitors’ thoughts in the future section. We used a similar technique for the testimony session as well, to combine another discussion session for students to talk about “how to be a responsible global citizen” with the speakers. With many atomic bomb exhibitions often only emphasizing the “past,” our exhibition was unique in the way we asked visitors to go beyond the past, allowing them to think about the current situation with a critical eye. With this purpose, we had 209 people come to our events in total.

Title: NEXT GENERAL TALK (NGT)
Quote:
Next Generation Talk, organized in partnership with Guediawaye Hip Hop (GHH), promoted youth civic
engagement in four localities of Dakar’s marginalized periphery by organizing a series of six conferences
that served as dialogue spaces where the high values and ideas of democratic institutions were brought
to local youth. Each event followed a similar preparation rhythm: in the period leading up to a given conference, we
contacted organizers in that locality with whom we had existing relationships and created a rough event
plan. Then, we selected experts from our roster of possible panelists and began promoting the
conference, as well as inviting distinguished locals whose attendance or even active participation in the
event might enrich youth attendees’ experience (especially if youth might otherwise have very limited
access to these individuals). In the days preceding a conference, we began transporting and setting up
equipment (e.g. tents, chairs, audiovisual gear, etc.) at the event location. On the day of the conference,
our staff and panelists would meet and get familiar with the event timetable and any other salient details.
Before starting, a moderator, usually from GHH, also reviewed goals and strategies for effectively
engaging young people and communicating complex ideas to them. (In retrospect, this was perhaps one
of the best measures we took, and we probably should have done it even more.) Then we’d begin.  I believe our project helped youth begin to self-orient on
identifying problems, framing and theorizing them in civic and actionable terms (i.e., for our conference
participants themselves to take steps to address the problems they identify), and on where and how to
seek further education on coordinating to overcome collective action problems. Indeed, our conferences
convened and familiarized youth with local civil society leaders, and made them aware of opportunities to
affiliate themselves with formal civil society, which were frequently highlighted as important vehicles for
realizing local and national development because it is through them that international exchange is
possible.

Title: OPEN: Optimizing Pathways for Equitable Neighborhoods
Our Pride Project
Quote:
To me, peace is an unconditional goal that is achieved only when the rights of all people, regardless
of their identity, are respected, upheld, and protected, so all various communities can live in safety and
exist in harmony. I believe that my project has been able to contribute to peace through promoting inclusion
and the rights of the LGBTQIA+ community. Filled with the passion to help others recognize their very existence, I
founded Our Pride. The name “Our Pride” denotes the sheer joy and courage in fighting against stigma and
discrimination based on gender identity, sexuality, and sexual orientation in order to take ownership of
individual, authentic selves. This project is indeed dedicated to everyone; it exists to let everyone recognize
and take pride in their own identity–sexuality, gender identity, gender expression, and sexual
characteristics. Through this project, I learned about the varying circumstances within the families of many
queer friends and the common ambition in striving for acceptance from their own families.

Title: Paper to Pixels
Quote:
This project initially set out to address the impact of digital technology on education, focusing on the transition from paper-based learning to screen-based mediums and its implications for students’development. As the work unfolded, however, the focus evolved into a broader exploration of the culture surrounding personal devices, specifically smartphones, which shape nearly every aspect of our daily lives. The project set out to address the national issues of depression, anxiety, disconnection, and screen addiction. I chose documentary filmmaking as the medium because it is both my field of study and
a form of storytelling that can simultaneously captivate and educate audiences.I define peace as the cultivation of understanding within our circumstances. An inner stillness that
can shape our outer reality. In the context of this project, peace emerges when individuals recognize their
relationship with technology and reclaim agency over how they live, learn, and connect with others.

Title: Partitioned Past, United Future: Being Desi in India and Pakistan
Quote:
The ‘Partitioned Past, United Future: Being Desi in India and Pakistan’ sought to address the lack
of humanization and people-to-people contact between youth of India and Pakistan by creating dialogue
between students in Delhi and Lahore. Over eight weeks, participants engaged in structured online
dialogues, in-person cohort sessions, guest speaker events with experienced peacebuilders, and
designed their own community-based projects to foster empathy and reconciliation across borders. For the purposes of this project, ‘peace’ was defined as the re-definition of relationships heavily
influenced by hostility, historical amnesia, and political and cultural discourse between two countries. We
understood peace not just as the absence of violence but as the presence of relationships,
understanding, and shared responsibility.  
In our view, the project was highly impactful in contributing to this idea of peace: while this was
small-scale, 7 participants from Delhi and Lahore each (14 total) engaged in conversations with each
other. In the short term, we observed participants moving beyond binary ways of thinking. Their
conversations challenged preconceived notions and fostered more nuanced perspectives about the
“Other.”  Participants also designed community-based projects to apply their learning. The
projects included: a heritage documentary on Delhi and Lahore as “tale of two cities,” a fashion initiative
around South Asian peace, an open mic series about India–Pakistan suffering, a history project on the
River Beas, unpacking the relationship between women and the India-Pakistan relationship and creating
a letter exchange amongst school going children in the two countries, amongst others. These were highly
creative, fruitful and gave the participants a chance to understand their role in peacebuilding and the
forms of internal reflection needed.
For many, it was the first time engaging in a cross-border dialogue, which shifted how they
understood cultural and societal assumptions. In the long term, we see participants investing deeply in
their peace projects, with aspirations to scale them up. Several expressed interest in pursuing
peacebuilding as part of their broader life trajectories, signaling that the projects and conversations may
have lasting influence beyond this summer.

Title: Pathways to Wellness: Promoting Housing Security through Knowledge, Opportunities, and  Empowerment
Quote:
In Pathways to Wellness, we worked to address disparities in resource availability that individuals who are unhoused face in their daily lives, including inaccessibility to basic hygiene products, fresh produce, stable employment, wellness opportunities, and healthcare. Our team defines peace as the absence of conflict, violence, and uncontrollable hardship, alongside the presence of acceptance and comfort with one’s state of being. By supporting empowerment,independence, and well-being, our project may encourage inner peace for individuals facing housing instability. Although we have always considered ourselves optimists, the increase in violence and division in the world can sometimes make society feel as though it is trending toward an “every man for himself” mentality rather than unity. Through this project, we learned that when given the opportunity, people are eager to step forward, collaborate, and make a positive difference. This reinforced our belief in the power of community and the importance of creating spaces for collective action. Furthermore, the project challenged us to adapt quickly and develop practical solutions, strengthening our critical thinking and
problem-solving skills.

Title: Peace Lab Ethiopia: Youth Leadership in Science, Advocacy & Children's
Quote:
The project was initiated out of the team’s passion for supporting our community and addressing challenges faced by
Ethiopian youth, including limited access to education, social inequality, and displacement. Recognizing that peace
involves the realization of human rights, we designed a seven-day program guided by the UN Convention on the Rights of
the Child, with each day focusing on a specific right such as education, gender equality, participation, digital literacy, and
environmental sustainability. Students engaged in hands-on activities, mentorship, collaborative research, workshops with
experts, and field visits, applying learning in practical contexts. Our approach emphasized experiential learning, civic
engagement, and solution-oriented thinking, equipping students with advocacy, leadership, critical thinking, and problem-
solving skills while fostering a STEM-driven, innovative mindset.  Peace is built on a profound understanding of challenges and is stabilized through trust and patience.  
Having colleges and collaborators who share a vision and want to jointly follow a purpose is a great leaf of hope even
when it gets complicated. We define our project as peacebuilding, because our goal was to institutionalize the idea of a
Peace Lab with academic legitimation, to build a house for collaboration and expression of the topics of our time. Yet, we
have come to realize that it is the passion behind the process and the engagement of the participants that brings light to
the house and makes it a safe haven in times of crisis. Projects for Peace was an imperative for everyone involved to live
according to a joint definition of peace and to continuously develop it in collaboration to share it. The biggest value that
this project brought is community – the 16 participants grew into a community of changemakers and peers beyond their
scholarly ambition, just as students from German universities and Institute for Peace & Security Studies now connected knowing that there is so much
more peace to build.

Title: Peace Through Childcare
Quote:
Jali Watoto (“care for children” in Kiswahili) began when we saw mothers in Kisumu
missing critical medical appointments because they had no safe place to leave their children. Partnering with hospital administrators, community health promoters, and childcare specialists, we built two free childcare and breastfeeding centers so mothers can prioritize their health while knowing their children are cared for.  Peace comes from having autonomy to care for one’s inner well-being. For mothers, such
peace is hard to achieve when sacrifices on the child’s behalf are expected. The mission of Jali Watoto is
to alleviate mothers of the difficult choice between her child’s safety and her own health. We hope to
promote peace of mind for mothers as they simultaneously prioritize their own health and take care of
their children. Jali Watoto has helped over 6,000 mothers and children and introduced a sense of fun and
play for children at the hospital. While we were there, we saw the benefits of a happy space for mothers
as well. One young mother invited us to jump rope with her and throw a ball around while her baby was
taking a nap. Other parents are simply happy to see their child happy. These short-term benefits extend
into long-term benefits as there are fewer barriers for patients to attend their hospital appointments. For
mothers and children especially, we would expect higher rates of vaccination/treatment and increased
appointment attendance which could lead to improved follow through on treatments that need several
visits.

Title: Peace with Time
Quote: I initiated this project to support caregivers, a role and labor that has long been neglected in hospice care and for people with special needs. With the growing aging population worldwide, the question of how to care for our own aging families or families in need has become a universal concern. Peace with Time seeks to create a space for caregivers to practice self-care and share their stories through photography and storytelling. I began sending out cameras and holding online conversations with previous interviewees and new participants. Many participants shared that the film camera became a valuable medium for remembering the loved ones they care for and for creating new memories. This process has evolved into a form of healing and creative therapy, enabling caregivers to become artists documenting the precious time they spend with those they care for.

Title: PFAS and Environmental Justice Awareness Film
Quote:
‘PFAS and You’ is a documentary film that provides an in-depth but accessible explanation of
many issues surrounding the spread of PFAS (Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances) in today’s world,
including their persistence, presence in the environment, health effects, and the current state of
environmental injustice related to the spread of these chemicals.
The film includes expert testimony from three different non-profits, in-the-field journalism, and
archival research and footage.
Alongside the film, a lengthy informative article was developed, aimed at diving deeper into the
specifics of the PFAS crisis, and two public screenings were arranged, both online and in-person,
complete with a panel discussion with leading experts in public health and chemical exposure to foster
community attention and action.I believe peace comes from awareness and access to the truth, giving individuals the power to
make informed decisions about their health, and the ability to speak up for causes that will benefit them
and their community. In this sense, PFAS and You contributes to this by bringing to light many aspects of toxic
chemical contamination that are not well-known to the public, such as the role of chemical manufacturers
and the EPA in allowing this contamination to occur long after the chemicals were determined to be toxic.
This gives the public peace-of-mind through clarity on these complicated topics, and opportunities to
contribute. I found that many of the people I spoke to throughout the making of the film had never heard
of PFAS and were shocked to hear about the implications these chemicals have for health and the
environment.

Title: Project Isa Lang
Quote:
Project Isa Lang (meaning “only one” in Tagalog) is a place-based environmental education
initiative that centers Sibuyan Island’s globally unique ecology to foster community-led conservation and
youth engagement. Working to address threats from deforestation, biodiversity loss, and the erosion of
local ecological knowledge, the project partnered with local educators at Teresa Bernas Memorial School
to co-develop interactive lessons and activities that make complex environmental concepts accessible to
students, cultivating pride, responsibility, and hope for Sibuyan’s natural heritage. The program combines classroom instruction, experiential outdoor learning, and
thoughtful reflection activities. Each day of the first week, we introduce a core ecological theme, central to
Sibuyan’s unique story–such as island isolation, adaptation, and endemism. These concepts are key to
understanding Sibuyan's importance, while providing necessary context on the broader importance of
biodiversity. In the second week, we move beyond the classroom to hands-on outdoor experiential
learning, connecting students with the ecosystems that surround them. In coordination with local guides
and the DENR, students will explore a Biodiversity Assessment Monitoring System Transect (BAMS)
set-up within the forest of the Bernas-Basa property.

These lessons and activities came alive through participative weekly development meetings with
the head science teacher, Sir Gerald Ruda, where we worked with our team of volunteers to design,
refine, and adapt lesson plans that reflected the uniqueness of the island’s ecology. Throughout the
summer, we worked closely with Sir. Gerald and the school principal to strengthen the project’s
sustainability: supporting his understanding and contributions to the lessons, instilling confidence to
administer them after our departure from Sibuyan, and ensuring that the program fit into the school’s
long-term vision. These locally collaborative efforts in program development are also reflected in our
lesson plan testing. Fifteen local children, all of whom are recent graduates of TBMS, played a critical role
in piloting the lessons and activities. By testing the lessons with them first, we were able to observe which
activities sparked the most engagement, which concepts needed clarification, and how best to pace each
session. Their feedback directly shaped the design of this pilot program, assuring that it is accessible,
enjoyable, and relevant to the lived experiences of similarly aged youth. Additionally, under the guidance
of our project mentors of the Ingle Trust Foundation of Davao and Philippine herpetologist Camilla
Meneses, we strived to strengthen the program’s scientific grounding and pedagogical design. Their
expertise ensured that our curriculum not only communicated key ecological concepts but also reflected
best practices in EE. Our work with place-based environmental education this summer demonstrated to
us that building lasting peace requires a localized-intimate approach and a deep understanding of the
narratives that shape a place. By grounding lessons in Sibuyan’s unique ecology, we saw how students’
pride can grow into a foundation for conservation and community peace.”

Title: Project Ma'man
Quote:
Project Ma’man was created to help sexual assault survivors in rural AlSweida build a better life for themselves. This was achieved through a free, confidential mental health platform in addition to on- ground workshops and other healing activities.
Few organizations operate in AlSweida, and from those, almost none have enough resources or are willing to help survivors due to fear of backlash. Project Ma’man chose a hybrid model to face these challenges: the website and on-ground relief efforts.
Our approach relied on Medup and the Syrian Family Planning Association (SFPA). Medup provided culturally informed therapists and a welcoming space for survivors, while SFPA trained our volunteers and gave our project the credibility and trust it needed. After completing volunteer
training, our city and the community we planned to serve were attacked by terrorists in a multi-day
assault that claimed thousands of lives. During this chaos, our on-ground work stopped, and we
could only provide online support.This experience pushed us to expand our project
to support everyone while keeping a special focus on survivors of sexual assault.
We sought to elevate mental health, something often overlooked. We organized vigils, workshops,
and other events to encourage the use of our platform and to console people during difficult times. Our website is still active and supporting people; we continue to coordinate
workshops and distribution efforts daily, and our volunteers remain committed to providing safe
spaces, reducing stigma, and supporting healing across the region.Our project contributed to peace by giving
survivors and their communities access to support systems that were previously nonexistent. In the
short term, we saw people come together in vigils, workshops, and donation drives to support one
another. In the long term, by normalizing conversations about mental health and sexual assault, we
believe we planted seeds of cultural change that will continue to grow.

Title: Providing Clean Drinking Water For School Children In Sankhatar, Nepal
Quote:
This project tackled the problem of unsafe drinking water in Nepal’s Terai region by partnering with
SmartPaani to install tailored filtration systems in two public schools in Sindhuli, form student hygiene
clubs, engage parents through community workshops, and build a community water storage tank to
address shortages and contamination. Together, these efforts provided safe water for over 800 students
and 50 staff at Shree Saraswati Secondary School and Shree Baljyoti Primary School, while also
fostering resilience, ownership, and long-term change within the schools and surrounding community. “Through this project, I learned that peacebuilding is as much about the process as the outcome.
Unexpected challenges forced me to reimagine my approach time and again. I began with a proposal for
a single school, but by staying responsive to community needs and pivoting when necessary, I was able
to amplify the impact and provide safe drinking water for over 800 students and 50 staffs.” -Bishal Khadka

Title: Pull up a Chair: Art workshops and health education to promote peace among people living with HIV and AIDS
Quote:
For my project, I worked with two community based organizations in western Kenya: the Western
Focus Community Organization (WEFOCO) and the Western Organization for People Living with
HIV/AIDS (WOPLAH). We launched a new community goat-rearing program, created a safe space where
young mothers could braid hair to raise money and supported art programs in schools.Since finishing my project I have been reflecting on what I think peace is and how my working
definition changed. Peace is a privilege. Peace is knowledge and learning. Peace is economic stability.
Peace is good health. Peace is security. Peace is conversation. Peace is well being and the absence of
conflict. I will keep working to extend peace for the rest of my life.

Title: Pyari Education
Quote:
Through Naya Paila, I learned that peace is not an abstract ideal but a process of equipping
people with knowledge, dignity, and agency over their own bodies. This project taught me that
peace is not achieved through information alone, but through education that people can
understand, internalize, and use in their daily lives. I learned that when young people are given
creative, inclusive, and empathetic ways to learn about their bodies, relationships, and rights,
they gain the agency to challenge stigma and prevent cycles of violence. The Projects for
Peace grant gave me the opportunity to see how pedagogy itself can be a peacebuilding tool,
and I will carry forward the lesson that lasting peace begins with transforming how we teach.  This summer Pyari Education through the Naya Paila (“a new step”) campaign sought to
advance inclusive and creative sexual and reproductive health (SRH) education in Nepal by
combining workshops, needs assessments, and digital innovation. Through sessions with
marginalized groups, school-based research, and the launch of our first digital learning platform,
we laid the foundation for a nationwide curriculum and future community-based programs.

Title: REborn: Youth-Veteran Integration Project for IDPs and Veterans in Chahor and Boyany villages
Quote:
REborn empowered youth, veterans, and internally displaced persons (IDPs) in remote villages of Chahor and Boyany by establishing reintegration centers. Through educational, cultural, and sports resources—including English language course, stocked library, and small gym area— REborn fostered reintegration of marginalized communities and formed local civil culture. True peace is the weaving of communities where veterans, displaced persons, and youth can flourish together, sustained by ongoing commitment to trust and inclusion between groups divided by war.
  This project contributed to peace by addressing the needs of marginalized communities and promoting their integration into a broader civic environment. By focusing on veterans and IDPs, the initiative reduced social polarization and fostered a greater sense of belonging in the remote areas of Chernivtsi Oblast. Beyond equipping youth-veteran centers in Boyany and Chahor, which now serve more than 700 individuals, the project created opportunities for growth through a carefully curated English course, access to libraries, and sports programs.   This project profoundly changed how I think about the world and my place in it. Working with veterans and IDPs—people who lost everything but still embody extraordinary resilience—reminded me of how fragile and precious life is. I lived in two realities: one where people grapple with visible and invisible traumas daily, and another where many remain unaware of this suffering altogether. Bridging these realities has inspired me to continue working in the field of veteran reintegration and advocacy.

Title: Reclaiming Low-income BIPOC Neighborhoods in NYC from Anti-Feminist and Machismo Views through Public Art Peace-Making Initiatives
Quote:
My project addressed gender-based violence and the erasure of marginalized voices in Uptown
Manhattan by organizing public art workshops where community members co-created designs rooted in
healing, resistance, and collective memory. I worked with over 120 residents at Revolution Books, a
bookstore located in Harlem, and a local public park, Riverside Park in Washington Heights, and together,
we began the process of designing a community mural that is currently in progress.This project changed the way I think about peace and the world: I now understand it not as an endpoint but as a series of intentional choices: listening, slowing down, centering those most affected, and
embracing the lessons of both elders and youth. It deepened my commitment to public art as activism, but
also as everyday care.

Title: Sciventure Carnival
Quote:
Our project contributed to peace by reducing educational inequity and sparking curiosity in children who
often feel excluded from modern learning. In the short term, students gained exposure and excitement for
STEM; in the long term, teacher training has the potential to sustain learning cycles, gradually
transforming educational culture in rural areas. The project emerged from an observation that children in rural Pakistan often lack engaging opportunities
to explore science beyond textbooks. STEM subjects are frequently taught in a rote, exam-focused
manner, which limits creativity, critical thinking, and curiosity. Recognizing this gap, we designed the
Sciventure Carnival as a platform to make STEM accessible and exciting, using interactive exhibits and
models to encourage learning through discovery.
Our main strategy was to create a community-centered science fair, where children could see practical
